heading: Two arrests made over body in Bambalapitiya school
content:
Two individuals have been arrested ,today, (April 22nd) on suspicion in connection to the body that was found at a storage facility at a school in Colombo 4 and have been remanded until the 27th of this month.
According to the police, the security officer at the school and another individual alleged to have met the victim have thus been arrested. The police had stated that the arrested individual who had visited the deceased in school has had a close relationship with her. They further added that the suspects were identified based on the call logs of the deceased.
Police went on to add that the suspects will be produced before the Aluthkade Magistrate on Wednesday, April 22. The victim who is suspected to have been murdered was found in a storage room at the school. Police noted that the woman had sustained injuries to her face.
Her family said that she had been working at the school as a janitor for fourteen years.

heading: Rajanganaya Reservoir spill-gates open
content:
Several incidents occurred around the country owing to  inclement weather conditions.
Two spill gates of Rajanganaya Reservoir were opened on Tuesday, April 21, owing to heavy showers in the area. Our correspondent noted that sluice gates were opened by one foot each.
Meanwhile, heavy showers were experienced on April 20 causing the reservoirs of Walasmulla, Kakiobada and Kirama to overflow. As a result, paddy lands in Tangalle and the Tangalle – Weeraketiya road were left inundated.
Irrigation Engineer for the Weeraketiya Provincial Council K.N.S Kumar said that fifty acres of paddy land were left inundated.
The Disaster Management Centre noted that with the inclement weather conditions,  water levels of Kalu River, Aththanagalu Oya and several rivers have increased. Assistant Director of the DMC Pradeep Kodippili warned villagers to be cautious of the rising threats.

heading: Not ready to transfer powers of the President to the PM: ...
content:
Deputy Minister Vijith Wijayamuni Soyza made a statement at a public gathering at the Siyabalanduwa Cultural Centre and noted that they are not ready to transfer the powers of the president to the prime minister.
He further noted that Wimal Weerawansa and Gammanpila want to create a rift in the party and the UNP.  He stated:
The executive powers cannot be transferred from one body to another by vesting the power of the President to the Prime Minister. This move cannot be endorsed.
He went on to note that they are not in this government with fear and that they are ready to leave at anytime.

heading: Basil Rajapaksa arrives at FCID to provide statement rega...
content:
Former Minister Basil Rajapakse has arrived at the Financial Crimes Investigation Division to provide a statement with regard to alleged financial irregularities that took place at the Divi Naguma Deprtment.
Police Media Spokesperson ASP Ruwan Gunasekara stated that the former minister was summoned as per the orders of the Kaduwela Magistrate.

heading: Neymar’s goals allow Barcelona to reach semi-finals
content:
Neymar scored twice as Barcelona reached the Champions League semi-finals for the seventh time in the last eight seasons by comfortably beating Paris St Germain 2-0 yesterday to complete an emphatic 5-1 aggregate victory.
The Nou Camp crowd were brought to their feet for Neymar’s first goal as midfielder Andres Iniesta ran from his own half, skipping past three challenges, before delivering a perfect pass for the Brazilian, who rounded keeper Salvatore Sirigu and slid the ball home after 14 minutes.
Barca coach Luis Enrique stated that their goal is to be the two best teams in Europe and therefore we must not set any ambitions with the kind of players we have and the work they have done all over this season. The goal is to be better than the next team we face in the semi-finals and show on the pitch that we are worthy of moving to the final.

heading: Over 150 year old Champagne bubbles from the sea
content:
Every wine connoisseur knows the value of an aged wine, but few get the opportunity to sample 170-year-old Champagne from the bottom of the sea.
In 2010, divers found 168 bottles of bubbly while exploring a shipwreck off the Finnish Aland archipelago in the Baltic Sea. When they tasted the wine, they realized it was likely more than a century old.
A chemical analysis of the ancient libation has revealed a great deal about how this 19th-century wine was produced.

heading: Urubokka resident stabbed – suspect flees
content:
A person has been killed after being attacked with a sharp weapon.
Police stated that the victim was attacked with a sharp weapon while he was on his way to a relative’s house with his wife. The victim has been identified as a 37-year old named Kandilpanage Dayananda a resident of the Ginnaliya area in Urubokka
Police further noted that despite identifying the suspect, he has fled the area. No arrest has been made so far.
The remains of the victim is currently lying at the Matara General Hospital.

heading: Sam Smith nominated for Ivor Novello Award
content:
Sam Smith has been nominated for a prestigious Ivor Novello Award.
The 22-year-old is up for the award with his song Stay with Me in the most performed work category. He faces competition from Clean Bandit for their track Rather Be and George Ezra with Budapest.
The annual awards are now in their 60th year and celebrate songwriting and composing. The gongs are voted for by writers and this year they will be presented at a ceremony in London, UK, on May 21.
The announcement tops off a recent stint of awards and acclaim for Sam after he scooped four Grammys in February, including song of the year for Stay with Me and pop record of the year for In the Lonely Hour. He also received two Brits and the track is nominated for four Billboard Music Awards.

heading: Medical officers in Western Province commence strike
content:
The Association of Government Registered and Assistant Medical Officers have commenced a token strike on Wednesday, April 22.
The protesters stated that the strike comes in the wake of “illegal transfers” made for the year 2015, thus violating the policies adhered to when making such transfers.
The Secretary of the Association of Government Registered and Assistant Medical Officers, Dr. C.W.S. Kumarage allege that these transfers were made illegally without complying with the rules and regulations.
The following allegations were made – that the Director General of Medical Services of the Western Province issued the transfers on  April 2, whereas it should have been given in January. A request was made to her regarding this matter previously as well but it wasn’t taken into consideration which has led to this strike, which is scheduled to go on until the transfers are removed. The strike is expected to be carried out at all base hospitals and district hospitals in the Western Province.

heading: Today is World Earth Day
content:
Today, April 22, is World Earth Day. It is celebrated as an annual event by people all across the world  in order to increase the awareness among people on environment safety as well as to demonstrate  environmental protection measures.
In 1969, at a UNESCO Conference in San Francisco, peace activist John McConnell proposed a day to honour the Earth and the concept of peace, to first be celebrated on March 21, 1970, the first day of Spring in the northern hemisphere.
A month later, a separate Earth Day was founded by United States Senator Gaylord Nelson as an environmental teach-in first held on April 22, 1970.
While this April 22 Earth Day, was focused on the United States, an organization launched by Denis Hayes, who was the original national coordinator in 1970, took it international significance in 1990 and organized events in 141 nations.
Numerous communities celebrate Earth Week, an entire week of activities focussed on environmental issues.

heading: UPFA parliamentarians end Satyagraha (Watch video)
content:
A Satyagraha launched by a group of UPFA parliamentarians against the decision to summon the former president to the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption commenced in the evening of Monday, April 20, along with the adjournment of the Parliament, concluded on Tuesday April 21.
The group of MPs remained overnight within the parliament chamber. They charged that unless a reasonable response to their request was granted by the Speaker, they would not conclude the Satyagraha.
Meanwhile, earlier in Parliament, Speaker Chamal Rajapaksa announced to the house that he should be informed prior to the summoning of any MP to the Bribery Commission.
Parliament was adjourned for a further fifteen minutes when tensions flared following a statement made by Minister Ravi Karunanayake.

heading: Landslide warnings for Ratnapura, Kandy, Badulla, Kalutar...
content:
The National Building Research Organisation states that the risk of landslides persists in six districts due to the inclement weather conditions experienced over the country.
Director of the the Landslide Monitoring Unit R.M.S. Bandara says that warnings have been issued to the districts of Ratnapura, Kandy, Badulla, Kalutara, Matara and Galle.
Director- Landslide Monitoring Unit R.M.S. Bandara noted that landslide warnings were issued to six districts namely Kalutara, Galle, Matara, Ratnapura, Badulla and Kandy districts on Tuesday, April 21 from 6 p.m to 6 p.m. on Thursday, April 22.
Within the Badulla district, areas of Haldamulla, Passara and Bandarawela have been identified as landslide prone areas.
Furthermore, the areas of Imbulpe,Balangoda, Palmadulla, Elapatha and Kalawana Divisional Secretariats which fall under the preview of the Ratnapura district have also been issued landslide warnings. Landslide warnings have also been issued to several divisional secretariats including Ingiriya in the Kalutara District.
In the Galle district, areas of Thawalama have been as landslide prone areas. In the Matara District, the  areas of Pitabaddara,Mulathiyana have also been issued warnings.
Meanwhile, the Udumahanuwara divisional secretariat which falls under the Kandy district is considered as a landslide prone area. The public have been asked to be cautious when travelling along the Ella-Wellawaya road and Mahiyanaganaya-Kandy road as there is a risk of landslides and rock slides occurring in the ares owing to the inclement weather condition.

heading: Russians in costumes jump in ice-cold water on skis and s...
content:
Funpark in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk played host to an unusual winter sporting event on Sunday, April 19 with skiers in costumes racing downhill to end their run in a pool of cold water.
A yearly contest drew 111 ski and snowboard fans who wore costumes ranging from Super Man, Zorro, to a giant piece of cake, in an event that saw participants rushing down a snow-covered hill and jumping into a cold pool of water.
Most of the contestants did not manage to slide a long way across the pond, however this did not cool down their excitement.
Spectators cheered as show participants fell into the pond.
This year people of various age ranging from 9 to 68 joined the competition. However only seven participants managed to slide across the pond and finish dry shod.
 
Source- Reuters

heading: Gotabhaya calls on President Sirisena to join hands with ...
content:
In an interview with The New Indian Express former secretary of defence Gotabaya Rajapaksa has called on President Maithripala Sirisena to join hand with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa to give Sri Lanka a “functioning government.”
Rajapaksa went on to note that President Sirisena has the ability to call for early parliamentary elections and appoint Mahinda Rajapaksa as his Prime Minister. Gotabhaya believes that this will allow the country to get back on its feet.
Speaking to P.K. Balachandran of The New Indian Express the former defence secretary had claimed that Sri Lankans want Mahinda Rajapaksa in power, adding that support for the former President had grown beyond the 5.8 million votes he got in the January Presidential Election.
In his interview, the former defence Ssecretary claims that there is no functioning government as Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, former President Chandrika Bandaranaike and several other ministers are vying for power within the present government. He goes on to state that all economic development projects initiated by the Rajapaksa regime have come to a standstill and that over 100,000 workers have been rendered jobless as a result of this.
Rajapaksa claims that civil servants are frightened to make decisions as officials are currently being investigated by the government for alleged procedural lapses. Gotabhaya Rajapaksa warns that if this trend is allowed to continue, the entire economy would collapse and it would be difficult to put the country back on its feet.
Responding to the corruption charges levelled against him the former defence secretary denied the allegations as baseless, stating that he had earned money for the country through his projects.

heading: Tense situation erupts at NWPC over summoning of former P...
content:
A tense situation erupted in the North Western Provincial Council over the summoning of former president Mahinda Rajapaksa to the Bribery Commission.
A debate arose based on a statement made by Chief Minister of the North Western Province, Dayasiri Jayasekara at the commencement of the meeting.
Provincial Councillors from the government carried placards and commenced protesting in the middle of the council thereby wreaking havoc.
Chairman of the North Western Provincial Council Dharmasiri Dassanayake left the chamber with the mace during the demonstration
Our correspondent noted that the group of provincial councillors  continued with the protest for ten minutes.
CM Dayasiri Jayasekara said that they can see the manner in which Ranil Wickremesinghe who took oaths and pledged to re-establish good governance, is running the government, adding that he is violating  the rule of law.
Speaking further, he said that the Prime Minister has appointed a one-sided team to investigate corruption which took place at the Central Bank where 41 billion was lost within 2-3 hours.
The opposition too convened a media briefing after which the government provincial councillors staged a protest in close proximity to the area.
Opposition Leader J.C. Alawathuwala said that when they are trying to implement what the people want, and what they suggested, they start protesting. This has now spread to provincial councils.
Meanwhile, North Western Provincial Councillor Prasanna Shamal Senarath said that they are all major rogues and extortionists who stole this country for 20 years. That is why it is not easy to stop a protest with regard to catching these rogues. He said that this country will never get better without chasing these thieves away.

heading: Take steps to give appropriate response to corrupt politi...
content:
Dr. Mahim Mendis says that the people must undoubtedly take steps to give the appropriate response to corrupt politicians at upcoming elections.
Speaking to News1st, Civil Activist Dr. Mahim Mendis says that we need to remind the people of this country that, at this moment, extremely immoral and irrational forces are coming forward to stand for what’s wrong and what’s right for democracy.

content:
A protest was launched on Tuesday April 21, by a group of UPFA supporters on the road leading to Parliament. The protest was launched opposing the summoning of former president Mahinda Rajapaksa to the Commission to investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption.
The protest  commenced at the  Parliament Roundabout. The protesters later paraded on the streets towards the parliamentary complex,  hindering vehicular movement.

A police officer said that an order has been issued to stop the protest from proceeding any further as this is a high security zone. He went on to state that the commencement of this protest would hinder the movement of vehicular traffic and cause inconvenience to the general public.
However, the group of UPFA supporters continued their protest until a group of MPs engaged in a demonstration in the parliament chamber came to meet the protesters, with the Speaker’s decision.
The group dispersed once the MPs brought the Speaker’s communicated the Speakers decision.

heading: Japan’s Maglev train breaks world speed record
content:
A world speed record was set by Japan’s state-of-the-art Maglev Train in a test run near Mount Fuji, clocking more than 600km/h (373mph).
The seven-car maglev short for “magnetic levitation” train, hit a top speed of 603km/h and managed nearly 11 seconds over 600km/h. The new record came less than a week after the company clocked 590km/h, by breaking its own 2003 record of 581km/h. The maglev hovers 10cm (four inches) above the tracks and is propelled by electrically charged magnets.
The service, which would run at a top speed of 500km/h, is expected to connect the two cities in only 40 minutes, less than half the present journey time in the shinkansen bullet trains. By 2045 maglev trains are expected to link Tokyo and Osaka in just one hour and seven minutes, slashing the journey time in half. However, construction costs for the dedicated lines are astronomical estimated at nearly $100 billion for just the stretch to Nagoya, with more than 80% of the route expected to go through costly tunnels.
Japan wants to sell its Shinkansen bullet and magnetic train systems overseas. The prime minister, Shinzo Abe, is acting as a travelling salesman in chief in his bid to revive the Japanese economy, partly through infrastructure exports.
Source:BBC

heading: Mahinda Kahandagama released on bail
content:
Chairman of the Employment Association Mahinda Kahandagama, was released on bail on Tuesday April 21 after being remanded on charges of financial fraud.
He was released on a Rs 100,000 bail and four sureties worth Rs 5 million each.
Having granted bail, the Colombo Chief Magistrate Gihan Pilapitiya, ordered that the suspect should avoid collecting money from retail outlets under the purview of the Colombo Municipal Council.
The magistrate also noted that the AG will file a report to the court regarding the suspects involvement in financial fraud and added that, if found guilty, the suspect’s bail would be cancelled.

heading: World’s largest kidney removed from a patient in Delhi
content:
Indian media reports that world’s largest kidney weighing at 2.75 kilogrammes has been removed by a group of Indian surgeons from a person who was suffering from Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease.
The patient who marked the record was suffering from autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) for a couple of years and was admitted to the Sir Ganga Ram hospital(SRGH) last month following chronic renal failure with severe pain in abdomen and the passing of blood in urine.
Surgeons of Sir Ganga Ram Hospital in Delhi arrived at a decision to remove both the kidneys of the patient as a life saving procedure, while the other reason was the deteriorating condition despite being admitted to the hospital.
However, the three hour long surgery was quite successful.  Consultant Urological Surgeon at SGRH Dr. Manu Gupta, the one who performed the long surgery which lasted for three hours said that the procedure was quite challenging as a normal kidneys weigh 130 grams approximately whereas this kidney weighed 2.75 kgs which is 20 times more and was stuck to the surrounding intestines.
“Even the second kidney of the patient also weighed 2.5 kilogrammes and had to be removed in an another surgery a week later,” Gupta said and added that altogether, the patient’s body was bearing an extra weight of about 5 kilogrammes.

heading: Veteran Journalist D.F. Kariyakarawana passes away
content:
Veteran journalist, D.F Kariyakarawana passed away on the morning of  Tuesday April 21 at the age of 93, following a prolonged illness.
Born in the Kurana area in Negombo, Kariyakarawarana first entered the field of  print media in 1946 with a series of poems and short stories. He was a founding member of the editorial board for the Lankadeepa newspaper, when it was established in 1947. Later,  he joined the  Dinamina newspaper in 1951.
D.K. Kariyakarawana also wrote for Dinamina and Silumina and rendered a great service by training numerous journalists. In respect of a request made by Kariyakarawana, his body will be handed over to the Neville Fernando Hospital in Malabe, following religious observances for a period of 24 hours.

heading: Nokia to return to market it “once dominated”
content:
Nokia plans to go back to manufacturing mobile phone in 2016. The company is said to be “quietly plotting a return” to the market it once dominated.
Nokia Technologies is reportedly driving the move back to mobile phones. The division is in charge of managing Nokia’s large portfolio of over 10,000 patents – it released the N1 Android tablet in China earlier this year, as well as the Z Launcher for Android.
The Finnish manufacturer will follow a similar approach to the phone market as it did with the N1 tablet. It will design the devices, but let another company handle their manufacturing and marketing.
Nokia recently acquired the networking equipment manufacturer Alcatel-Lucent. The company is also said to be contemplating a sale of its HERE maps division.

heading: CSK worth Rs 5 lakh only? New IPL governing council not a...
content:
In a fresh controversy, Chennai Super Kings owners have valued their team at Rs 5 lakh only. According to reports, the IPL governing council, headed by Rajeev Shukla has not accepted this valuation. The issue is expected to be discussed during Sunday’s BCCI working committee meeting.
Chennai Super Kings and their owners have been under the scanner ever since the 2013 IPL match-fixing and betting scandal broke. Gurunath Meiyappan, a team owner and the son-in-law of former Board chief N. Srinivasan, has been indicted by a Supreme Court panel for betting and sharing team information. A US company valued CSK to over Rs 450 crore last season.
In January, the Supreme Court brought charges of “conflict of interest” against Srinivasan. The charges denied Srinivasan from contesting the BCCI presidential elections. Acting on the court order, India Cements, the original owners of the CSK, transferred shares to Chennai Super Kings Cricket Ltd.
India Cements Board decided that the subsidiary will be owned by existing shareholders on a proportionate basis. While 70 per cent of India Cements shares are held by public, promoters hold 28 per cent and N Srinivasan holds 0.14 per cent of the shares.
Reports suggest that the IPL governing council is not happy with CSK’s new value and has not ratified the transfer of shares. As per the BCCI rules, 5 per cent of the sale price of any team must be given to the BCCI. Effectively, BCCI will get Rs 25,000 only.
CSK and their owners are still under the Supreme Court scanner. The new ‘value’ will generate more controversy for sure.
Source: NDTV

heading: ‘Everybody Loves Raymond’ child actor commits...
content:
Sawyer Sweeten grew up before the eyes of millions as a child star on the endearing family sitcom Everybody Loves Raymond. Early Thursday he committed suicide, his sister Madylin Sweeten said in a statement.
He was 19.
“This morning a terrible family tragedy has occurred,” Madylin Sweeten said in a statement passed on by her manager Dino May.
“We are devastated to report that our beloved brother, son, and friend, Sawyer Sweeten, took his own life. He was weeks away from his 20th birthday. At this sensitive time, our family requests privacy and we beg of you to reach out to the ones you love.”
Sweeten, best known for his role Geoffrey Barone, was visiting family in Texas, entertainment industry magazine Hollywood Reporter reported, where he is believed to have shot himself on the front porch.
Sawyer Sweeten was born in May 1995 in Brownwood, Texas.
He was a year and a half old when he started on “Raymond,” playing next to his real-life twin brother Sullivan, who starred as Michael Barone, according to the website IMDb. Their sister, Madylin, played their TV sister Ally Barone.
The show was about the adults, and the children, especially the twins, had bit parts, adorable cameo moments. In the beginning, they were too young to speak.
The series developed a loyal following and ran from September 1996 through May 2005.
According to his IMDb profile, Sawyer did not appear to take on acting roles after “Raymond” was discontinued.
Source: CNN

heading: Legal action to instituted in incidents involving elephants
content:
The Wildlife Conservation Department says that legal action will be instituted against those connected to 18 incidents of holding elephants without a permit.
Director General of the Department M.D. Ratnayake stated that the department had also taken eleven elephants into its custody. It is learnt that the elephants  had been kept in captivity illegally.
It was reported that the department, along with the Criminal Investigations Department, had investigated several complaints relating to the illegal captivity of elephants
The Director General added that, at present, officers within the Department had been taken into custody by the CID as well in connection to the illegal captivity of elephants.
In the meantime, convening a media briefing, the National Movement to Protect Domesticated Elephants stated that there is an strong attempt to destroy the concept of domesticated elephants.
Chairman of National Movement to Protect Domesticated elephants Venerable Magalkanda Sudassi Thero said:
There is a strong attempt to do away with domesticated elephants. Also we say it clearly and with much responsibility that there are certain environmental  groups, certain activists and certain non-governmental organisations which have acquired powers that are greater than the powers of the relevant minister and deputy minister.
It is very clear that the underlying objective of these elements is to remove elephants from the perehera culture. Therefore, we have decided that until this issue is resolved none of our members will be releasing elephants for pereheras.

heading: New poll shows Switzerland is ‘world’s happie...
content:
The land of clocks and chocolates is the world’s happiest country, according to a new survey.
Switzerland topped the third annual World Happiness index produced by the Sustainable Development Solutions Network (SDSN), an initiative under the United Nations. It was closely followed by Iceland, Denmark, Norway and Canada.
Togo, Burundi, Benin and Rwanda, with civil-war wracked Syria, were least happy. The World Happiness Report examined 158 countries and is aimed at influencing government policy.

 
The study bases its rankings on data from the Gallup World Poll and takes into account variables such as real GDP per capita, healthy life expectancy, corruption levels and social freedoms.
“Increasingly happiness is considered a proper measure of social progress and goal of public policy,” the report said.
“A rapidly increasing number of national and local governments are using happiness data and research in their search for policies that could enable people to live better lives”.
The SDSN is comprised of people from academia, government and the private sector and was first launched in 2012.
Meanwhile Srilanka has been placed in 132nd position among the happiest countries.

 
Source: BBC

heading: Google shares rise after online ad sales drive revenue hi...
content:
Google Inc reported higher quarterly revenue and profit as rising online ad volume offset a hit from the strong dollar, sending the Internet company’s shares higher in after-hours trading.
Shares of the world’s No. 1 Internet search engine rose after the results were released, climbing 3.5 percent on Thursday to $577.
While revenue and profit missed the forecasts of Wall Street analysts, many investors had been bracing for a weaker report, said BGC Financial analyst Colin Gillis.
The company has faced challenges in mobile advertising and is running up more expenses as it invests in new businesses.
“The concern was that the first quarter results could have been much worse,” Gillis said. “There’s a certain degree of relief rally happening.”
Revenue for the quarter that ended in March rose 12 percent to $17.26 billion, from $15.42 billion a year earlier. Analysts on average had expected revenue of $17.5 billion, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
The rising dollar took a toll on results at Google, which generates about half of its revenue overseas.
“Excluding the net impact of foreign currency headwinds, revenue grew a healthy 17 percent year on year,” Google Chief Financial Officer Patrick Pichette said in a statement.
The number of ads, or paid clicks, rose 13 percent, while the average price of online ads, or “cost per click,” declined 7 percent.
Google’s ad revenue has been pressured as more consumers access its online services on mobiles devices such as smartphones and tablets, where ad rates are typically lower.
In a conference call, Pichette highlighted mobile ads as a key source of revenue growth during the quarter. “We are experiencing real strength in mobile search,” he said.
The contribution of ad revenue from video platform YouTube “continues to grow at a strong rate year-over year,” he added. Brands are embracing YouTube’s TrueView service, where advertisers pay only when users opt not to skip an ad, he said.
Google’s advertising sales in the first quarter rose 11 percent to $15.51 billion. (bit.ly/1OLAPb8)
The company, under increasing competition for mobile ad dollars from rivals such as Facebook Inc, tweaked its algorithm for mobile searches on Tuesday to favor sites that look good on smartphone screens. (bit.ly/1yMzbno)
Earlier this month, the European Union accused Google of abusing its dominance of Internet searches to push its own products.
Net income rose to $3.59 billion, or $5.20 per share, from $3.45 billion, or $5.04 per share.
Excluding items, the company earned $6.57 per share, just missing analysts’ forecast of $6.60.
Source: Reuters

heading: Here is a look back at the 100 day program (Watch Video)
Plans afoot to introduce new polio vaccine
content:
The Ministry of Health says that steps will be taken to introduce a new polio vaccine from the 1st of July 1, this year.
Director General of the Epidemiology Unit of the Ministry of Health Dr. Paba Palihawadana said that measures will be taken to provide this vaccine, along with the other vaccine that is currently administered.
The new vaccine will be introduced as part of the National Immunisation programme and will be used for four month old infants.
The aim of introducing the new polio vaccine is to eradicate polio globally as the virus has been completely eradicated in 65 countries thus far.
The Epidemiology Unit noted that there have not been polio cases reported in Sri Lanka from the year 1993. The unit added that at present the polio virus is widespread in countries such as Pakistan, Afghanistan and Nigeria.
The ministry also noted that it is mandatory for four months old infants to be vaccinated prior to visiting countries in which polio is widespread.
Meanwhile, the World Health Organization has declared a vaccination week starting from April 30, with the objective of eradicating polio globally.

heading: MP Basil Rajapaksa transferred to the National Hospital
content:
Former Minister Basil Rajapaksa has been transferred to the Merchants ward of the Colombo National Hospital, according to a hospital spokesperson.
MP Rajapaksa was arrested on Wednesday (April 22nd) by the Police Financial Crimes Division (FCID) and was later remanded till the 5th of May after being produced before the Kaduwela Magistrate. The parliamentarian was later moved to the prison hospital before being transferred to the National Hospital.
Former Minister Basil Rajapaksa was arrested along with Former Secretary to the Ministry of Economic Development Dr. Nihal Jayatilleke and Former Director General of the Divi Neguma Department R.A.A.K. Ranawaka.
Earlier on Thursday (April 23rd) all three suspects were produced before the Chief Judicial Medical Officer of Colombo based on an order issued by the Kaduwela Magistrate. Attorney-at-Law Kamal Wiyasasiri who appeared on behalf of one of the suspects stated that the Kaduwela Magistrate ordered the prisons department to ensure that MP Rajapaksa be provided the required facilities to attend Parliamentary proceedings.
According to the Attorney-at-Law, three charges had been filed against MP Rajapaksa and the two suspects who were arrested with him. The charges include misappropriating funds of the Divi Neguma department. The attorney went onto note that two of the charges fall under the “Public property act.”
The three suspects including Basil Rajapaksa were taken to the Prisons Hospital from the Magistrate Premises close to mid-night yesterday. Meanwhile, a group who had gathered opposite the court premises behaved in an unruly manner.
A group including Former Minister Susil Premajayantha visited Basil Rajapaksa at the Prisons Hospital on Wednesday night. Meanwhile Former Secretary of Defense Gotabaya Rajapaksa arrived at the Prison Hospital this morning to visit Basil Rajapaksa.

heading: “Basil Rajapaksa is not afraid of facing charges un...
content:
Commenting on the arrest of former Minister Basil Rajapaksa, Deputy Minister of Highways & investment Promotion, Eran Wickramaratne stated that the former Minister Basil Rajapaksa is not afraid to face charges unlike the rest of his family.
However Deputy Minister Wickramaratne noted that if Basil Rajapaksa was an ordinary person he would have been sent straight to prison instead of being allowed to go to a hospital.
Commenting on statements being made that former President Mahinda Rajapaksa cannot be brought before court, the Deputy Minister stated that this is a false notion as former President Chandrika Kumaratunga was summoned before court on an earlier occasion. Wickramaratne noted that law cannot be enforced differently even for former presidents.

heading: I warned Basil that he would be arrested: Mahinda Rajapaksa
content:
Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa revealed on Thursday that he warned his Brother Basil Rajapaksa that he would be arrested if he returned to the country.
Speaking to the media during an event in Matale, the former president stated that MP Basil did not heed his advice as he did not want to be labelled a thief. According to Mahinda Rajapaksa, Basil Rajapaksa returned to the country because he believed that he had committed no act of wrong-doing.
Commenting on the current Director General of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption, the former president stated that there are a number of allegations against her as well. He noted that the current director general allegedly cleared 50 acres of land in the Knuckles Reserve.

heading: Min. Amaratunga comments on the arrest of MP Basil Rajapaksa
content:
Minister of Public Order John Amaratunga says that those charged of wrongdoings should be brought to book. Addressing a media briefing in Colombo on Thursday (April 23rd) the minister stated that the arrest of someone, who is charged with committing a malpractice, following investigation is not something new.
The Ministers statements were prompted by the arrest of MP Basil Rajapaksa by the Police Financial Crimes Investigation Division (FCID) on Wednesday (April 22nd). Min. Amaratunga went on to note that if the parliamentarian is proved to be not guilty, then he would be freed.
The Minister of Public Order reiterated that Sri Lanka is a democratic country and it is their responsibility to safeguard the authority of the rule of law.
Responding to questions raised by journalists regarding the summoning of former Defense Secretary Gotabaya Rajapaksa before the bribery commission, the minister stated that Gotabaya Rajapaksa does not need to fear the summon if he has not committed any act of wrongdoing.
The minister was also questioned about the manner in which public who gathered at the Kaduwela Magistrate’s court, when MP bail Rajapaksa was brought in, behaved. The Minister stated that a majority of the people who had gathered there were brought to the location after offering bribes of alcohol and food. Min. Amaratunga noted that they have the democratic right to express their opinion as long as they do not break the law.

heading: SLFP to support 19th amendment, 20th amendment to be adopted
content:
The SLFP central committee has decided to support the proposed 19th amendment to the constitution.
This was confirmed to News1st by SLFP spokesperson MP Dilan Perera. The SLFP central committee meeting is currently underway in Colombo under the auspices of President Maithripala Sirisena.
Dilan Perera went on to note that the President had assured the SLFP central committee that the 20th amendment to the constitution would be adopted as soon as possible and that Parliament would be dissolved thereafter.

heading: Panadura residents protest against stalled road developme...
content:
Area residents of Gorakaana, Panadura engaged in a protest against the abandonment of the road development activities along the Old galle road on Thursday (April 23rd). The protest was carried out in Gorakaana, Panadura.
The area residents engaged in the protest by obstructing the old galle road saying that they are faced with various difficulties due to the abandonment of the road development work.

heading: Seventy year old killed in Puttalam wild elephant attack ...
content:

Our correspondent said that the victim was attacked while on his way to his paddy fields.
Residents of the area held a protest on Thursday demanding a solution to the wild elephant menace.

heading: Draft bill on new electoral system submitted to cabinet
content:
The draft bill for the new electoral system has been submitted to the cabinet.
Gayantha Karunathilaka, the Minister of Mass Media and Parliamentary Affairs said that the draft bill was submitted to cabinet that convened by President Maithripala Sirisena on Wednesday.  He added that an extensive discussion took place in this regard.
The draft bill recommends of a mixed electoral system incorporating the first past the post and proportional representation system.
The minister further added that all parties have the opportunity to provide their ideas and suggestions with regard to the draft bill. Thereby, the draft will be taken up for discussion on Friday.

heading: Investigations underway into death in Kahathuduwa
content:
An individual has died at Sri Skandakumara Devalaya in Heraliyawala, Polgasowita in Kahathuduwa.
Police said that the individual died after falling during an argument. Police added that the deceased was involved in argument with two other people on the morning of Wednesday April 22 and that one of them had allegedly pushed him.
However, as the cause of death remains suspicious, police investigations are underway.
Police further added that two individuals have been arrested over suspicion. The body is currently lying at the Kalubowila Teaching Hospital.

heading: Soldier rescues woman in Matara
content:
A woman who attempted to commit suicide by jumping into the Nilwala river has been rescued. She was rescued by a soldier stationed at the Matara Army Camp.
Our correspondent stated that the incident took place at around 10 p.m.
The identity of the woman has not been revealed. However,she has been admitted to the Matara District Hospital.

content:
The Sri Lanka Army says that approximately 16,000 soldiers who had been absent without official leave had made use of the amnesty period and left the army.

heading: Al Jazeera forced to go off air in India (Video)
content:
Al Jazeera today only showed a blank screen with a message saying that “As instructed by the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, this channel will not be available from 00.01 hours on 22nd April till 00.01 hours on 27th April 2015.”
International news channel Al Jazeera was today forced to go off air in the country for five days as the government penalized it for repeatedly showing wrong maps of India.
Al Jazeera had shown a wrong map of India in some of its broadcasts in 2013 and 2014, after which the matter was referred to Surveyor General of India (SGI).

heading: New Zealand PM apologizes Auckland woman for hair-pulling
content:
New Zealand’s Prime Minister John Key has publicly apologized to an Auckland waitress for pulling her ponytail while visiting her cafe.
The un-named waitress wrote in a blog that he had tugged her ponytail on several occasions, even after she had asked him not to.
This embarrassing apology comes after the anonymous woman posting a contribution to the blog on Wednesday, accusing the prime minister of harassing and bullying her.
The waitress wrote on the Daily Blog that the hair-pulling started during last November’s election campaign, when Mr Key’s National Party was re-elected.
However he had apologist and gave the woman two bottles of wine.
Mr Key’s office said in a statement: “His actions were intended to be light-hearted. It was never his intention to make her feel uncomfortable and he has apologized to her.”
Mr Key told reporters on Wednesday that he had “a very warm and friendly relationship” with staff at the cafe where “we have lots of fun and games there, there’s always lots of practical jokes and things”.

content:
The demonstration opposite the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery of Corruption concluded earlier Thursday afternoon.
The demonstration concluded subsequent to the departure of Former Secretary of Defence, Gotabhaya Rajapaksa who had arrived at the Commission.

heading: Catholic Bishops Conference expresses stance on 19th Amen...
content:
The Catholic Bishop’s Conference in Sri Lanka, stated its stance on the proposed 19th ammendment to the constitution.
They stated that the 19th Amendment is a step in the right direction when taking the efforts of Mother Lanka, as it attempts to curtail the unlimited powers of the Executive Presidency and to ensure that democratic structures for good governance are established.
Issuing a statement bearing the signatures of Archbishop of Colombo, His Eminence Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith and the Secretary General Right Reverend Dr. valence Mendis, the Catholic Bishops Conference says the establishment of the Constitutional Council and other independent commissions, is imperative for the future of the country.
Furthermore, they note that the repeal of the 18th Amendment will pave the way to strengthen the independence of the judiciary and uphold the principles of law.
The Catholic Bishops Conference urges all parties to set aside their ideological differences in the greater interest of the nation and approve the constitutional reforms introduced by the 19th Amendment.
However, the statement reads further that if there is any clause that has to be placed before the people at a referendum as recommended by the Supreme Court, this procedure should be followed.

heading: Dept says special train services in place for Vesak
content:
The Railways Department says that steps are being taken to provide special train services in lieu of Vesak.
Speaking to News1st, General Manager of the Department Vijaya Amaratunga stated that these train services will be centered around the Kalutara and Kelaniya areas.
In the meantime,  the Railway Control Room states that train services along the coastal line have been restored.
Services along the line were suspended after a carriage carrying fuel jumped tracks at the Galle Railway Station at around 4.30 Wednesday evening.
Railway services between Galle and Matara had to be suspended as a result.

Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa who visited Puttalam on Wednesday April 22, commented on his participation in a possible discussion with President Maithripala Sirisena.
