heading: Mystery illness strikes cows in Anuradhapura, Batticaloa,...
content:
Two hundred (200) cows in several districts have died suddenly, with authorities still trying to ascertain the underlying cause.
The Department of Animal Production and Health says cows were reported dead from the districts of Anuradhapura, Batticaloa, Polonnaruwa and Ratnapura.
According to the Director of the department’s Health Unit, S. A Shivasothi, the Livestock Research Department is investigating into the mystery illness.
Seventy eight (78) cows from the Welikanda area, 70 cows from Batticaloa, 70 from the Palagala area in Anuradhapura and 30 from Kuruwita have been reported dead.

heading: Agrarian Insurance Board to pay compensation to farmers
content:
The Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board has stated that farmers will be paid a compensation on May 9 owing to the crops that have been damaged since last year.
Director General Panduka Weerasinghe stated that the calculations are closing in on its final phase.

heading: S.M. Marikkar says no need to fear elections as Mahinda R...
content:
Following are some of the views that were expressed by political representatives at event in different parts of the country.
Minister of Internal Transport, Ranjith Maddumabandara, stated that during the previous government when several persons earned money, the farmer remained poor but in this Government the money that only reached the the hands of those who obtained commissions is directed towards the poor.
At the Kalutara District meeting MP Rohitha Abeygunawardena stated that they are searching for a ring that which values up to 2.7 million or 2.8. This ring should be worn in the belly and not in the finger. The Prime Minister is jobless and he is weighing rings and calculating the value of the ring.
UNP Western Provincial Councilor S.M. Marikkar made a statement at an event held to distribute light bulbs and batteries for poor families in Kolonnawa.
He noted that Basil Rajapaksa , Dallas Alahapperuma and Gotabhaya Rajapaksa who have dual citizenship also cannot contest in the presidential election since they are patriotic American citizens. There is no need to fear the presidential election since Mahinda Rajapaksa cannot contest.

heading: Min. Premadasa says 19A approved with sole strength of th...
content:
Minister Sajith Premadasa states that the 19th Amendment to the constitution was approved with the sole strength of the president, despite criticisms.
He made this comment at an event held in Hambantota.
The laying of the foundation stone of the new building for the Sooriyawewa National School was held under the auspices of Minister Sajith Premadasa.

heading: Procession carrying Sacred Hair Relic to Sirasa – J...
content:
The procession carrying the sacred hair relic and the relics of the Maha Rahath theros to the Sirasa – John Keells Vesak Zone commenced on Wednesday morning.
The procession began its journey after a special Theva ceremony that took place at the Nelligala International Buddhist Centre.
The Amisa Pooja which initiates the celebrations of the Sirasa – John Keells Vesak Zone commemorating the three stages of Lord Budha’s life will take place at the MTV / MBC Head Office premises located at Braybrooke Street , Colombo 02.
The Sacred Hair Relic of Lord Buddha and the relics of the Maha Rahath Theros were brought to the Nelligala International Buddhist Centre where the Maha Sangha presided over the religious observances and rituals.
The event took place opposite the Sri Shakyasingha ‍Pagoda in Nelligala and was attended by senior officials of The Capital Maharaja Organisation Limited, John Keels Group and many others.
A Dhamma Book including a number of Gathas that is to be distributed amongst the devotees at the Sirasa – John Keells Vesak Zone was presented to the Maha Sangha.
The special chest in which the relics were placed was then moved in to the procession carrying them to the Sirasa – John Keells Vesak Zone amidst the chanting of Pirith.
The procession reached Galagedara through the Aladeniya Junction and then Mawathagama and Uyandana.
Devotees who were on either side of the road received the opportunity to pay homage to the sacred relics.
The processions stop for the day was the Ridee Viharaya in Kurunegala.
The procession carrying the sacred relics will commenced its journey from the Ridee Viharaya in Kurunegala at 07 on Thursday morning.
The procession will then make its way to the Thalgodapitiya Junction Ibbagamuwa, Kurunagela and then proceed to Narammala and Metiyaganae on the Negombo Road and arrive at the Mayurawathi Raja Maha Viharaya.

heading: Former president expresses views on 19th Amendment (Watch...
“19th Amendment, a historic victory” – ...
content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says the adoption of the 19th amendment to the constitution with a two third majority in parliament, is a historic victory for the Sri Lankan people.
Issuing a statement the Presidential Media Division said that President Sirisena thanks all stakeholders who contributed to this effort. President Maithripala Sirisena says that this victory is the result of a 37 year long struggle undertaken by the active citizens of Sri Lanka, adding that it is his belief that this victory is relevant not only for today but for future generations as well.
President Sirisena thanks all stakeholders who contributed to this effort, including the Maha Sanga, religious leaders, political parties and civil society groups, active citizens, who struggled, sustained and enriched the discourse on this amendment.
The President specially thanked the Members of Parliament and political parties who supported this amendment.
The statement reads further that though Presidential candidates had promised to abolish the Executive Presidency at five previous Presidential Elections, this is the only time it could be made a reality.
In his statement President Maithripala Sirisena goes on to say that this is a major step taken to strengthen the democracy of the country, as it was achieved constitutionally in compliance with the determination of the Supreme Court and also with the consent of all political parties.

content:
The police has decided to implement a special traffic and security plan in lieu of May Day which falls on Friday.
Police Media Spokesperson ASP Ruwan Gunasekara noted that around 2800 police personnel will been deployed for this purpose.
He also added that special traffic plans will be in place along T.B Jayag Mawatha , D.R. Wijewardena Mawatha , Vauxhall Street , Ibbanwala junction , Dharmapala Mawatha and Baseline road.
The police request motorists and commuters to use alternative routes during the May Day processions.

heading: Update : Hambantota mayor remanded
content:
Mayor of Hambantota Eraj Fernando was remanded till tomorrow (30th of April) after being produced before the Hambantota Magistrate court.
Earlier today the Police Headquarter’s Special Investigation Unit arrested Mayor of Hambantota Eraj Fernando.
Police Media Spokesperson ASP Ruwan Gunasekara had said that the Mayor was arrested in connection to a incident which occurred in March 2014 where Eraj Fernando attempted to assault and take away a suspect who was in the custody of the Ambalantota Police.

heading: Barcelona pulls ahead in La Liga
content:
Barcelona forwards Lionel Messi, Neymar Jr and Luis Suarez took their combined seasonal tally to over 100 goals, on Tuesday, April 28.
Luis Enrique and his star-studded squad took down Getafe, posting a 6-0 win at Camp Nou. Barcelona’s comfortable victory against mid-table Getafe stretched their unbeaten run to 15 matches, winning 14 and drawing one, in all competitions.
Barcelona who is already topping their table in the Spanish League extended their lead against rival Real Madrid in the table. Real Madrid currently stands second in the league with 79 points in 33 games and Barcelona continues its form at the top with 89 points from 34 games.
Barcelona looks to win the Liga BBVA but its line-up of hard matches do not end with the local league, as they will face Germany’s Bayern Munich in the first Champions League Semi-Final on May 5.

heading: A look at the fundamental changes brought about by 19A
content:
The significance of the 19th Amendment to the constitution is the curtailing of the powers of the Executive Presidency.
News1st takes a look at the fundamental changes that have been made with the new amendment.
One of the major changes made by the 19th Amendment is the establishment of the constitutional council, which in turn will re-establish the independent commissions.
The amendment will curtail the president’s powers in making appointments to major government institutions.
The establishment of a constitutional council and independent commissions through the 17th Amendment to the Constitution was weakened by adopting the 18th Amendment to the Constitution.
The 19th Amendment to the Constitution will repeal the 18th Amendment while replacing the now defunct 17th Amendment to establish the independent commissions.
The Constitutional Council will comprise of seven persons representing Parliament including the Speaker, the Prime Minister and the Opposition Leader as well as three other professionals.
The 19th Amendment to the Constitution will establish the commissions pertaining to the elections, state services, national police, audit services, human rights , investigate allegations of bribery or corruption, finance, national policy planning and university grants.
The powers that were vested with the president on making appointments to the aforementioned commissions as well as to appointing judges to the Supreme Courts have been distributed amongst the constitutional council and the commissions.
According to the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, the President’s term will be limited to five years while a president can only serve for two terms.
The president can only dissolve parliament four and a half year after the house of legislature has been elected.
The powers vested with the president on removing the Prime Minister have been abolished and replaced by the passing of a no confidence motion or the defeat of a budget.
However, the president will continue to serve as the head of the Cabinet and will be considered as a cabinet minister.
The new constitutional amendments note that the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers and their respective subjects will be decided by the president seeking the advice of the prime minister.
Also of significance in the 19th Amendment to the Constitution is that the Right to Information has been accepted as a Fundamental Right.
In addition, the audit process has been expanded and companies with over 51 percent of shares held by the government will come under the registration of companies act, paving way for an audit.

heading: Anagarika Dharmapala commemorated (Watch video)
Money Mayweather to take on the Pacman in Vegas
content:
The boxing world awaits the richest fight in its history as Filipino great Pacquiao and American legend Mayweather look to trade punches in their match against each other during the weekend. However Pacquiao had stated that it is this sort of underdog scenario where his killer instincts will kick in and that the American should be conscience that this might be his first loss.
Five-weight world champion Mayweather had responded to this stating that he will fight smarter and more calculated and it will be Pacquio’s recklessness that will lead to his fall.

heading: Prisoners sang ‘Amazing Grace’ in their final...
content:
Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, two members of the Bali nine who were executed alongside six other prisoners in Indonesia, sang ‘Amazing Grace’ in the moments before they were killed.
The group of prisoners sang hymns and refused to wear blindfolds as they were executed just after 12:30 am local time on Tuesday, Fairfax Media reports. The group was shot by a 13-member firing squad while singing ‘Bless the Lord O My Soul’.
“They sang one song after another. Praising God. They sang a few songs together, like in a choir. The non-Christian I believe sang from his heart. It was such an experience,” Pastor Karina de Vega, who had been present at the execution, told the news agency.
The eight men, convicted of drugs offences relating to smuggling, were executed by firing squad in Besi prison on the island of Nuksakambangan, despite widespread condemnation against the sentence and calls from the Australian government to delay the killings of Australians Chan and Sukumaran.
Australia’s Prime Minister Tony Abbott has already announced the country’s ambassador to Indonesia, Paul Grigson, will be withdrawn from Jakarta in direct response to the execution of the Australian pair, which he had called “both cruel and unnecessary”.
Chan, 31, and Sukumaran, 34, were arrested 10 years ago for attempting to smuggle more than eight kilograms of heroin to Australia as part of a group dubbed the Bali nine.
Chan married his Indonesian girlfriend, named as Febyanti, in prison just 48 hours before his execution.
The other six people executed included four Nigerian nationals, one Indonesian and one Brazilian man.
One woman, Mary Jane Fiesta Veloso, had been granted a stay of execution at the last minute while the Philippines investigates her case.
-Independent

heading: Former president says gazette notification is ‘very...
content:
Speaking in Kegalle on Tuesday, former president Mahinda Rajapaksa expressed his views regarding the gazette notification issued to establish the Police Financial Crime Investigation Division.
The former president noted that this gazette is “very dangerous” as it was issued stating that a separate Cabinet Sub Committee headed by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe be appointed to investigate cases of financial crimes and other major charges which will be selected only by the PM himself.
He went on to say that since this is through a gazette, he believes that the President will take action regarding the matter.
Former president Mahinda Rajapaksa arrived at the Dedhigama Rajamaha Viharaya on Tuesday to attend a Bodhi Pooja.

heading: SL medics treat over 400 injured in Nepal
content:
The Sri Lankan medical team that has commenced aid work in Nepal has treated 400 injured people thus far.
Major General Maithri Dias who is commanding the Sri Lankan rescue and relief contingent currently serving in Nepal said that patients with serious injuries have now been transferred to hospitals in Kathmandu after receiving initial treatment.
The Sri Lankan rescue and relief contingent are carrying out their operations from Dolalghad, a remote worst-affected area, about 60 kilometres away from Kathmandu, Nepal.

heading: Hospitals countrywide ailing due to shortage of nurses
content:
The Ministry of Health says that there is a dearth of upto 2000-3000 nurses in the country at present.
Deputy Director General of Research and training Unit of the Ministry Sunil De Silva says that the dearth of doctors is mostly seen in the Northern and the Sabaragamuwa Provinces.
The lack of nurses in certain provincial hospitals, has hindered the day to day functions at the hospital.  The Deputy Director General noted that the National and Sri Jayawardenpura Hospitals too suffer due to a lack of nursing staff.
He added that steps will be taken to enroll 2000 nurses before the end of next year.

heading: SL to compete in Asian Baseball Cup – East 6 Nations
content:
The Sri Lankan Baseball Team which will compete in the 11th edition of the Asian Baseball Cup-East 6 nations Tournament will leave the country on Friday. Speaking to Sports 1st, Captain of the Sri Lankan Team Iresh Kosala said that the team is determined to win the trophy at this tournament.
In addition to hosts Indonesia, Hong Kong, Philippines , Singapore, Thailand and Sri Lanka will compete in the tournament which will take place from May 2 – 8.
The Sri Lanka Team that will compete in the tournament took part in their final practice session on Tuesday at the Diyagama Mahinda Rajapaksa Grounds, Homagama.
The Sri Lankan team comprises of 18 players and they are coached by Korean National Park Chul-soon.
Sri Lanka will first play against Thailand on May 3 before moving on to the next stages.

heading: SL Army to send more soldiers to Nepal
content:
The Sri Lanka Army says that another deployment of soldiers are due to leave to Kathmandu on Wednesday April 29, to assist in the relief progamme.
Acting Army spokesperson Brigadier Jayanath Jayaweera stated that the soldiers will leave for Kathmandu at 8.30 a.m on Wednesday Morning on a SriLankan Airlines flight. Brigadier Jayanath further noted that the deployment consists of 13 navy personnel, 89 army personnel and seven doctors.
He also added that the flight will also carry 15,000 kilogrammes of medical equipment, water, and food items including 20,000 kilogrammes of dry rations provided by Sathosa.

heading: Indonesia executions: Australia recalls ambassador
content:
Australia has recalled its ambassador from Indonesia after two Australian men were executed for drug smuggling.
Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran were among eight people from several countries executed by firing squad shortly after midnight on Wednesday on the prison island of Nusakambangan.
Brazil’s government also expressed its “deep dismay” at the execution of one of its citizens, Rodrigo Gularte.But the execution of a Philippine woman was called off at the last minute.
Mary Jane Fiesta Veloso was spared after her government appealed to Indonesia, saying a woman she had accused of planting drugs on her had handed herself.
Australia had mounted a lengthy diplomatic campaign to save Chan and Sukumaran, convicted in 2006 of being the ringleaders of a group of Australian heroin traffickers known as the Bali Nine.
Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott said on Tuesday that the executions were “both cruel and unnecessary,” saying Chan and Sukumaran had been “fully rehabilitated” while in prison.
“We respect Indonesia’s sovereignty but we do deplore what’s been done and this cannot be simply business as usual,” he said.
“For that reason, once all the courtesies have been extended to the Chan and Sukumaran families our ambassador will be withdrawn for consultations.”
Indonesia is an important country to Australia, the BBC’s Jon Donnison says, with the two working closely together on asylum seekers and terrorism issues.
This is the first time Australia has recalled an ambassador from Indonesia, and its first ever recall over the execution of one of its citizens abroad.
Indonesian Attorney General Muhammad Prasetyo defended the executions, saying his country was fighting a “war” on drugs.
-BBC

heading: President Sirisena hails the passage of 19th Amendment
content:
The 19th Amendment to the Constitution which includes the reduction of powers vested with the executive presidency was passed with a majority in Parliament on Tuesday.
The final reading of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution was passed with 212 votes.
UPFA MP Sarath Weerasekara voted against, independent parliamentarian Ajith Kumara abstained from voting while eight members were absent.
After the vote, the house was adjourned for fifteen minutes following a tension-sparking request made by MP Dinesh Gunawardena for copies of all committee stage amendments.
Meanwhile, President Maithripala Sirisena has hailed the passage of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution with a 2/3rds majority in Parliament, as a historic victory for the Sri Lankan people. President Sirisena noted that it was a victory achieved following a people’s struggle that has lasted 37 years.
Issuing a statement, the President’s Media Division said that President Sirisena expresses his gratitude to the influence groups, the Maha Sangha, religious leaders, active citizens, civil society and all political parties and parliamentarians who used their vote to ensure this victory.
He added that the ability to fulfill this task constitutionally, in compliance with the determination of the Supreme Court and with the support of all political parties, is a giant step taken on behalf of democracy in the country.
The President concluded that the victory achieved today is a victory not only for the citizens of today but also for children yet to be born.

heading: Remembering a great leader – 22nd death anniversary...
content:
The 22nd death anniversary of late President Ranasinghe Premadasa, who is considered the first “commoner” to be at the helm of affairs, breaking a tradition of the top leadership being in the hands of the affluent, was marked on Friday, May 1.
The main commemoration event took place this morning opposite the Premadasa memorial in Hulftsdorp, Colombo.
Ranasinghe Premadasa who entered politics as a member of the Ceylon Labour Party contested at the poll of the Colombo Municipal Council and went on to become the Deputy mayor of Colombo and later was elected to Parliament in 1965.
The late president who had held a number of positions as the minister of local government and prime minister was also elected the second executive President.
He made a considerable  impact in the country’s political history as he showed special interest in housing projects for villages, the apparel industry and distributing free uniform material for students.
The 22nd commemoration ceremony which was organised in the vicinity of his statue in Colombo, on Friday was held under the auspices of President Maithripala Sirisena who said that late President Premadasa was a leader who solved the problem without waiting for it to seek his attention.
President Sirisena also added that Sri Lanka’s future should be shaped through the lessons of the late President.
Speaking at the commemoration event, Prime minister Ranil Wickremesinghe noted that the country cannot move forward without bringing together the people and protecting human rights.
The son of the late President Premadasa, Sajith Premadasa recalled the dream of the late President to create an all party administration. He noted that the late President’s attempts to join hands with the late Madame Bandaranaike and move towards an all party administration did not see the light of day due to various reasons. He went on to say that his late father’s dream has been created today.
Meanwhile, a group including Provincial Councillor S.M. Marikkar made floral tributes at the monument of late Ranasinghe Premadasa at the Wellampitiya Junction on Friday.
Speaking at the event, the UNP Western Provincial Councillor noted that the late president was the only UNP leader who walked the streets for the working class, achieved victory for them and paid for it with his life.
Thereafter the gathering in Wellampitiya commenced their rally.

heading: New heads of foreign missions present credentials to Pres...
Min. Rauff Hakeem expresses views on 19th Amendment
content:
Minister of Urban Development, Water Supply and Drainage,Rauff Hakeem  expressed his views in parliament on Tuesday evening during the debate on the 19th Amendment to the Constitution.
He noted that there is also an effort to introduce electoral reforms and that electoral reforms is an issue which concerns the entire nation.
He went on to add that there many parties that represent the minority with political interest concerning the minority and that these parties must be consulted in the process in introducing electoral reforms. He further added that those people who argue that the stability of a future government must be protected by introducing a system which will ensure that a party which gets past 50 percent of the vote, should have a stable government.
However he went on to add that this alone should not be the criteria and that in his opinion, stability should be by ensuring and accommodating minorities. He further noted that if minority interests and minority political opinions is not accommodated within the chamber of the house that in itself can destabilise the government and the country.
Minister of Resettlement, D.M. Swaminathan stated that the most fundamental issue is that the President of this country, who has been given the powers that has been vested in the 1978 constitution has come forward and democratically told the country, that he doesn’t want these powers and that he wants powers to democratically run this country.
He went on to add that the president is looking to run the country according to a democratic system involving the Prime Minister and the cabinet and the opposition’s efforts to not accept this only questions the same democratic powers that is being asked for.

heading: “we have always had the spirit and resilience to co...
content:
The 38th Annual Convention of the Capital Maharaja Organisation was held at the Stein Studios in Ratmalana  recently under the auspices of President Maithripala Sirisena.
Among other notable guests who attended this year’s Annual Convention were the executives of the Capital Maharaja Organisation, the Maha Sangha, experts from various fields, and politicians.
The highlight of the event was the selection of the Executive of the Year where five executives of the Capital Maharaja Group were nominated for the coveted award. it was Chandana Sooriyabandara, the Channel Head of Sirasa TV who bagged the coveted Executive of the Year Award for 2014 – 2015.
Here is a look at the full speech that was delivered during the annual convention on behalf of the Chairman of the Capital Maharaja Oraganisation,
 
CHAIRMAN’S SPEECH 2014/2015
Good evening Ladies & Gentlemen.
As I was writing this speech, I thought that 38 years is an incredibly long time for any convention to be held continuously, year after year, or for that matter, for someone to be working in the same organization, for that length of time.  In fact, my career spans an even longer period than that. What may be more interesting is that I have worked longer in this Institution, than the Founders, my Father and his friend, Mr. Mahadevan, did, and even longer than my brother, who is here with us today, who started before me but retired 15 years ago. Time really does fly.
[quote]There are over eleven hundred executives, and only the very best find themselves on the short list, and finally the best among the best gets the gold.[/quote]
In 1977 when the first EOTY was held in our Office Board Room at Bankshall Street, the numbers of Executives were few, there was no short list and the selection was easy.  Today, it is much harder than it was then.  There are over eleven hundred executives, and only the very best find themselves on the short list, and finally the best among the best gets the gold.
In comparison, just imagine what it takes, for one person, out of a population of 21 million, to be elected as The President, and that too up against a strong competitor.  A tough task, but it was done by someone, who is humble and unassuming, who took up the challenge and won.
Mr. President. Welcome to our Annual Convention. You deserve a big hand for the courage you displayed in coming forward, as the common candidate, against all odds, and for getting the 19th Amendment implemented with an overwhelming majority in Parliament.
You had the courage to be different, which incidentally, Sir, is the motto of our Group.
The defining moment of the dramatic result of our last Presidential election is, to my mind, an event that has as much significance for Sri Lanka and its people, as the end of the civil war.
[quote]we have been very active in this country’s commercial development for the last 85 years, since our inception and, we will continue to lead in all fields.[/quote]
Your Excellency, I hope you will agree with me that your victory, while it is a validation of your beliefs and values, is also a triumph of the will of the people, to make our country Sri Lanka a more democratic, equitable and, progressive one and a country that is more than ready to participate fully, in the comity of nations.
As for our Group, we have been very active in this country’s commercial development for the last 85 years, since our inception and, we will continue to lead in all fields. Additionally, we have provided opportunities to many, who are today highly sought after professionals in the media field.
[quote]We believe that our Media has played a significant role in setting standards in the electronic media culture, whether it be in entertainment, news or politics.  [/quote]
On the entertainment side, we have unearthed the hidden skills and talents of young men and women in our country through our Educational, General Entertainment and Reality programmes.  In News, we have not only been forthright and fearless, but also balanced and most of all sincere in our reporting.
Today, we play the role of watchdog, which is frowned upon by a few, but acknowledged and appreciated by many, especially our loyal listeners and viewers, who are in the millions locally and internationally.
Besides Media, we have maintained our emphasis on manufacturing and distribution, which is the foundation on which our Group has been built. We will take advantage of the forward thinking policies of the new government and, in the coming years invest further in expanding our Industrial operations.
We are therefore, in an unique position. On the one hand, to report on how the economy is moving, through our effective media and, on the other, play a major role in driving the economy through our multifaceted and diverse manufacturing, trading, distribution and export base. Setting an example for the rest.
[quote]Today, we play the role of watchdog, which is frowned upon by a few, but acknowledged and appreciated by many, especially our loyal listeners and viewers, who are in the millions locally and internationally. [/quote]
As the EOTY progresses today, you will learn more about our performance during the last financial year and, our plans for the future. Sashi, who was appointed joint Managing Director in November 2014, will elaborate on this during his presentation.
The new generation, both Pradeep and Sashi, will continue to take on additional responsibilities and, with the CEO of the Group and the Group Directors, take our Group to the next level.  In this connection, I would like to mention that they have already signed up an agreement with Kansai of Japan for the manufacture of Paints.  Mr. Bharuka, the Managing Director and Mr. Jain, a Director of Kansai NerolacIndia, who are present with us today, will speak about our joint venture later on this evening.
In life you can look at others and ask HOW, Or question yourself, and say WHY NOT. 85 years ago, our founders, two friends from the Rural North, were ambitious, dreamed big and, asked themselves, WHY NOT.  They came to Colombo and realized their Dream.
[quote]we have always had the spirit and resilience, to convert our dreams into reality.[/quote]
My brother & I also, had OUR dreams.
We expanded into Foods – Anchor was born.
We dreamed of providing mobile telephony – Dialog was born.
Our dream to enter the Media, blossomed into MTV & MBC.
Stein Studios is the realization of, yet another dream.
Most of all we kept our dreams intact, by not only surviving but also  being successful in the corporate world.
[quote]Therefore, let us continue to dream the impossible, and together achieve what others cannot even imagine. [/quote]
We at Maharajas are compulsive dreamers and so, we continue to dream, because we have always had the spirit and resilience, to convert our dreams into reality.
I am certain that those of you here, who are in your 20s & 30s and, even your 40s, are already dreaming big, which will result in taking our Group to even greater heights. It is my firm belief that, only in our Group do you have the opportunity and encouragement to realise your Dreams.
People like Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, Mark Zuckerburg, Jeff Bezos, Larry Page, Sergey Brin, Richard Branson and Ted Turner decided to chase their dreams and breaking away from convention, gave the world Apple, Microsoft, Facebook, Amazon, Google, Virgin and CNN. They made it happen. Today,  those Companies, are at the forefront of the international Corporate World touching every human-being on the planet.
Therefore, let us continue to dream the impossible, and together achieve what others cannot even imagine.
As I said last year, speaking from my heart to all of you, our Executives, we have reached where we have, the hard way.  We have to move ahead and remove any obstacles that may come between us and our dreams.  Believe in this truth.  This is our strength.  That is why we stand tall among the Sri Lankan corporates. Our leadership position must never be challenged.
Nothing will or can stop us, as we have the best human capital that can be found in the mercantile sector.
WE ARE THE MAHARAJAS
I leave you with a quote from Walt Disney:
“  All our dreams can come true, if we have the courage to pursue them “
-Walt Disney, 1901-1966
God Bless.

heading: Buddha Sasana Ministry offers advice on alms-giving events
content:
Ministry of Buddha Sasana and Religious Affairs has requested those organising alms-giving events as  Dansalas  to prevent using the Buddhist Flag to gather people.
Secretary Wasantha Ekanayake stated that advice will be given to use a flag coloured in yellow instead.
He went on to note that they have commenced raiding shops which display Buddhist Flag’s which are fakes.

heading: Paddy Marketing Board to sell part of stocks purchased
content:
The Paddy Marketing Board says that the paddy purchased during the Maha Season will be sold after converting it into rice.
Chairman of the board M. B. Dissanayake said that a part of this stock are to be kept as secured stocks.
The Chairman elaborating on the issue that that there are requests from some areas  for more paddy to be purchased. He said that the subject minister had forwarded this request to the cabinet for money to be released.
He said:
The money that we requested will be released soon and discussions are underway with the regard to what needs to be done to the purchased paddy.
He stated that as a result, the  ministry will be having necessary stocks while selling the rest to the public. He stated that the money earned through this exercise can be used to develop storage facilities.

heading: Kiribathgoda and Thirukkovil accidents claim lives
content:
Two youth have been killed in two separate motor accidents in the Kiribathgoda and Thirukkovil areas.
According to the police,  a 21 year old youth, a resident of Wattala, was killed when a motorcycle collided with a bus in the Mahara area on the Kandy road on the night of  Friday, April 24.
Meanwhile, a motor-cyclist was killed when his bike veered off the road in the Pottuvil area in Akkaraipattu, and hit a three-wheeler.
Police reports say that three persons who sustained injuries in the accident were admitted to hospital, but the motor-cyclist who was in a critical condition, succumbed to his injuries.

heading: Free Wi-Fi to be introduced on a single network
content:
The Information Communications Technology Agency (ICTA) says that the Free Wi-Fi service in the country will be introduced as a single network in the near future.
Programme Manager Gavaskar Subramanium said that at present, the service is being distributed through telephone network operators.
He Further noted that Free Wi-Fi is currently available at eighty public locations countrywide, and that they hope to increase it to 100 public locations by the end of this month.

heading: MP Basil Rajapaksa produced before Colombo Chief JMO
content:
The Prisons Department says that Former Minister Basil Rajapaksa, and two others, who were arrested for alleged financial irregularities said to have taken place in the Divi Neguma Department, have been produced before the Colombo Chief Judicial Medical Officer (JMO).
Commissioner General of Prisons Rohana Pushpakumara said that the three persons, including the Former Minister were produced before the JMO based on an order issued by the Kaduwela Magistrates Court.
The Commissioner General said that the future course of action will be taken based on the advise given by the JMO.
The Former Minister and two others were remanded until the 5th of May, by the Kaduwela Magistrates Court, after being arrested by the Financial Crimes Investigations Division on Wednesday (22nd April).

heading: Tokyo finds high levels of radiation in children’s ...
content:
Authorities in the Japanese capital have cordoned off a playground where high levels of radiation were detected this week, reviving concerns about nuclear contamination four years after the Fukushima disaster.
Nuclear regulators measured elevated radiation levels on Thursday in a children’s park in central Tokyo, city officials said, more than 250 km (155 miles) from the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant in northeast Japan.
One area of the park registered 480 microsieverts per hour, or nearly half the recommended annual limit of exposure.
That compares with radiation levels ranging from 0.7 to 23.2 microsieverts per hour measured this month in the air in Okuma, a town less than 20 km from the Fukushima plant.
It was not immediately clear why radiation levels were high in the park, which opened two years after the 2011 disaster. It has now been fenced off with an orange barricade, the city said.
“We are still checking what caused these elevated radiation levels and what type of radioactive substance it is,” said park representative Kyoko Tsujimura, adding that radiation elsewhere in the park remained low.
On Friday, television broadcast images of regulatory officials in work uniforms measuring radiation from a patch of dirt beside a colorful slide in the park.
The city has set up a health advice office to answer queries from concerned parents.
Thousands of people are still living in temporary shelters and have been unable to return home to hot zones closest to Tokyo Electric Power’s nuclear plant.
In the months after the nuclear meltdowns, concerned parents and citizens began measuring radiation levels in Tokyo schools and parks.
A drone with a small amount of radiation was found on Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s office building this week.
Source: Reuters

heading: Two Police officers critically injured in motor accident
content:
Two (02) Police officers have been critically injured in a motor accident that occurred near the Giri-pokunuwela area in Hettipola.
The Police Media Unit said that the accident occurred when a vehicle plying from Chilaw towards Kurunegala collided head on with a motorcycle plying in the opposite direction. A Police Sergeant and a Constable suffered serious injuries in the accident.
The injured Police officers were first admitted to the Hettipola Divisional Hospital before being transferred to the Kurunegala Teaching Hospital.

heading: Update : Basil Rajapaksa arrives (Watch video)
content:

Following the end of the presidential election, the former minister left the country to America on January 9.
Speaking to a group of journalists upon his arrival, he said that his sole objective is to provide answers to the charges leveled against him.
A group including parliamentarians.,provincial Councillors, close associates and supporters  were present to receive the former minister at the air port.
MP Basil Rajapaksa speaking to media said that there are usually  shortcomings when Political decisions are taken adding that he has taken responsibility for the defeat in his capacity as a National Organizer and a responsible Minister.
He went onto say that Rajapakse’s have been involved in Politics since 1931, there has not been a single incident of  robbing public property and funds.
When questioned by a journalist as if there is an election in the future from which electorate will he contest? he replied that his priority is to provide answers against allegations of bribery and corruption.

heading: Malta to bury 24 victims of latest shipwreck tragedy
content:
An Italian Coast Guard ship headed toward Sicily Monday with 27 survivors of what could be the Mediterranean’s deadliest migrant tragedy, as EU foreign ministers gathered for an emergency meeting on the growing crisis as migrants flee instability in Libya at unprecedented rates.
One survivor, identified as a 32-year-old Bangladeshi, has put the number of people on board the smugglers’ boat when it capsized near the Libyan coast at 950, and only a handful have been rescued. The survivor was flown on Sunday (April 19th) by helicopter to Catania, in Sicily, where he was interviewed by prosecutors and later treated in a hospital.
Earlier on Friday (April 20th), the Italian coast guard ship Gregoretti brought the bodies of 24 victims to Malta, where the dead will be buried.
All 24 were adult men, according to the Maltese Army.

heading: Leaders make key observations on party leaders’ mee...
content:
At the party leaders meeting held under the auspices of President Maithripala Sirisena on Sunday morning, an agreement was reached on the draft 19th Amendment to the Constitution.
At the meeting, party leaders including leaders of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party   directed the attention of the president towards electoral reforms.
President Maithripala Sirisena had made a pledge to party leaders that parliament will only be dissolved after electoral reforms are presented and adopted.
Chairman of Jathika Hela Urumaya Ven. Athuraliye Rathana Thera notes that the meeting was about the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, accordingly all agreed to adopt it, apart from the sections of the amendment that require a referendum and the section which was directed to the supreme court.
General Secretary of JVP Tilvin Silva says that if their aim is to abolish the Executive Presidency, then it will not happen through the 19th amendment to the constitution. He went onto say that they believe that even if the Executive Presidency cannot be fully abolished some powers of the Executive Presidency can be curtailed through this, therefore that too is some sort of victory.
Meanwhile, Parliamentary Group Leader of TNA R. Sampanthan points out that since the 19th Amendment to the Constitution is all about the powers of the Executive Presidency, that it is not an amendment which brings about a political solution to the national problem. He stated that it is with the view that that there needs to be some change in the way that this country should move forward
Ven. Maduluwawe Sobitha Thera noted that religious leaders and politicians will gather before Fort Railway Station on Monday afternoon and force all public representatives who represent parliament to render their support to adopting the the 19th Amendment to the Constitution.
Meanwhile, views were expressed about the 19th Amendment to the constitution on the Satana political debate programme telecast  on SirasaTV on Saturday night.
MP Faizer Mustapha noted that they need to revisit the Republican Constitution of 1972. That was a nominal presidency. But the content of the 19th Amendment is that there must be a President elected by the people. He went on to say that an agreement was reached that the President’s powers must be curtailed.
Meanwhile, Field Marshal Sarath Fonseka says the 19th Amendment will not be a solitary solution to all problems faced in the country.

heading: Sony launches smartphone Xperia Z4 in Japan
content:
Sony has revealed the Xperia Z4, its latest flagship smartphone on Monday (April 20th). The device was made public in an announcement in Japanese but there is neither an international launch date nor an accompanying ‘Compact’ version.
The Xperia Z4 is much like its Z3 predecessor, with the same 5.2-inch screen, a thinner 6.9mm form, and a Snapdragon 810 processor which clocks a more modest 2GHz but is eight-core and 64-bit. The rear-facing camera has the same eye-popping 20.7-megapixels, the front-facing camera has gotten a wide-angle lens, and elsewhere there’s 3GB of RAM under the hood and Android 5.0 Lollipop runs out of the box.
Sony is known for its water- and dust-resistant devices, and the Xperia Z4 also delivers on that front which is a controversial fact since the Samsung Galaxy S6 and S6 edge doesn’t contain these features
Sony had been rumoured to be considering an exit from the smartphone space, though its latest restructuring didn’t see that eventuality realized it remains a possibility in the future. The Xperia Z4 is another iterative product and, while the Xperia Z3 received positive reviews, it didn’t sell particularly well, which makes it hard to see how sticking to the same recipe will dig the company out of its rut on mobile.
But, if you’re an Xperia fan, stay tuned for details of the Z4’s international launch, which will come sooner rather than later now that the cat is out of the bag in Japan.
Source: Techcrunch

heading: Blatter calls for tougher action on racism in football
content:
FIFA president Sepp Blatter has called for tougher punishment for teams and associations found guilty of racism and discrimination and said monetary sanctions were increasingly ineffective.
Addressing the Confederation of African Football congress, Blatter reminded African countries of extensive financial support to the continent’s football associations from world football’s governing body as he opened the congress in a Cairo hotel on Tuesday (April 7).
Blatter, who is expected to get extensive support from the continent’s 54 countries when he stands for re-election next month, said FIFA had spent some $700 million on various programmes across Africa.
Blatter was met with a warm ovation from the African delegates in contrast to having to sit through stinging criticism when he attended the UEFA congress in Vienna last month. Tuesday’s CAF congress was also attended by Prince Ali bin Al Hussein of Jordan, Dutch Football Association President Michael van Praag and former Portugal international Luis Figo, who are all standing against Blatter, but they were not permitted to address the assembly.
CAF president Issa Hayatou, who last year pledged his members’ support to Blatter’s bid for another term in office, repeated his call for Africa to back the incumbent.

heading: Nepal hit by three-day strike (watch video)
content:
Nepalese riot police personnel detained at least one protester during a nationwide strike organised by the opposition alliance led by the Unified Communist Party of Nepal in Kathmandu on Tuesday (April 7).
The strikers want a new constitution drafted with the consensus of all political parties. Groups of protesters confronted police in the streets and at least one motorcycle and car were set alight.
Almost a decade has passed since the end of a civil war that pitted Maoist guerillas against the state and killed more than 17,000 people. Nepal’s political parties have repeatedly missed deadlines to write the new republic’s first constitution.
At the heart of the dispute is disagreement over creating new provinces based on ethnicity, a move backed by the former rebels.

heading: Turkish President Erdogan begins tour of Iran (watch video)
content:
Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan arrived in Tehran for a series high level meetings on Tuesday (April 7).
The visit has been expected for some time but some Iranian lawmakers had called for it to be scrapped last week after Erdogan publicly backed Saudi Arabia’s operation against Iran-allied Houthi rebels in Yemen and criticised Tehran for trying to “dominate the region.”
Erdogan, accompanied by a delegation of Turkish ministers, was greeted by President Hassan Rouhani. He is due to meet Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei, according to a statement posted on the Turkish presidential website on Saturday.
The two countries have strong economic ties, with sanctions-hit Iran being the second-largest gas supplier to energy-strapped Turkey, providing it with 10 billion cubic meters per year.
However diplomatic relations have suffered in recent years, with particularly sharp disagreements over how to resolve the civil war in neighboring Syria.

heading: Usage of Facebook linked to depression: Study reveals
content:
This is for all the Facebook users who spend a couple of minutes or hours stalking  others’ wall and comparing it with theirs.
The social media site  Facebook which can be used as an effective tool for connecting with new and old mates seems to be a cause of depression.
Some Facebook users feel depressed as they begin comparing what’s happening in their lives to the activities and accomplishments of their friends, reports Science Daily.
According to University of Houston (UH) researcher Mai-Ly Steers, this kind of social comparison paired with the amount of time spent on Facebook may be linked to depressive symptoms.
Steers conducted two studies to investigate how social comparison to peers on Facebook might impact users’ psychological health.
Both studies provide evidence that Facebook users felt depressed when comparing themselves to others.
The first study has found an association between time spent on Facebook and depressive symptoms for both genders.
However, the results demonstrated that making Facebook social comparisons mediated the link between time spent on Facebook and depressive symptoms for men only.
Meanwhile, the second study found a relationship between the amount of time spent on Facebook and depressive symptoms was mediated by social comparisons on Facebook. Unlike the first study, gender did not moderate these associations.
Steers said that people afflicted with emotional difficulties may be particularly susceptible to depressive symptoms due to Facebook social comparison after spending more time on medium.
For already distressed individuals, this distorted view of their friends’ lives may make them feel alone in internal struggles, which may compound their feelings of loneliness and isolation.

heading: Tiger Woods is back
content:
Former number one golf player Tiger Woods believes he is in the right shape to win a 15th major as he declared himself ready for the Masters, which begins on Thursday April 9.
Woods who is now ranked world 111, has been working on his game since carding a career-worst score of 82 at the Phoenix Open before injury saw him withdraw from the Farmers Insurance Open tournament
Woods aged 39 years mentioned that he feels like he has to get his game into a spot where he could complete to win a golf tournament said the 39-year-old.
Woods has not won a major since the 2008 US Open and the last of his four Masters wins was a decade ago, with the Californian only confirming on Friday that he would compete at Augusta.
He impressed in his practice round on Monday, showing no signs of the chipping “yips” which blighted his performance in Phoenix. Woods completed the front nine at Augusta alongside long-time friend Mark O’Meara, before playing the 10th and 18th alone.
Woods major championships are as follows:
Masters (4) – 1997, 2001, 2002, 2005
PGA Championship (4) – 1999, 2000, 2006, 2007
US Open (3) – 2000, 2002, 2008
Open Championship (3) – 2000, 2005, 2006

Facebook faces court battle over EU privacy laws
content:
Facebook is being sued by some 25,000 users for alleged violations of European privacy laws in a class action suit due in a Vienna court later. The claim, led by Austrian data protection campaigner Max Schrems, focuses on the way Facebook collects and forwards data.
It has been brought against Facebook’s European headquarters in Dublin, which registers all accounts outside the US and Canada. Facebook has not commented on the case.
More than 900 UK based users of the site are involved in bringing the case.
The legal action also claims privacy laws are breached in the way the networking giant monitors users when they use the site’s “like” buttons.
Mr Schrems, a law graduate, wants to stop what he calls mass surveillance by the social networking site.
He also alleges the company co-operated with Prism, a surveillance system launched in 2007 by the US National Security Agency.
The case includes a compensation claim of about €500 ($539;£362) per person. Mr Schrems has said that Facebook does not believe the case is admissible under Austrian law.
 
Source-BBC

heading: Yuvraj Makes Fun After Gambhir’s Bat Breaks at Eden...
content:
Kolkata Knight Riders skipper Gautam Gambhir is usually poised and composed at the crease. But on Wednesday as the IPL defending champions chased 169 versus Mumbai Indians, the elegant left-handed batsman suffered an ‘oops’ moment when his bat was broken into half. Gambhir charged down the crease to hit Vinay Kumar over covers off his very first ball and his willow snapped.
Vinay and Gambhir were once teammates at KKR while the man at the other end, Robin Uthappa plays with Vinay for Karnataka in the Ranji Trophy. There was some serious cricketing connection there. So much so that Yuvraj Singh, who has been snapped up by Delhi Daredevils took a dig at Gambhir on Twitter. Gambhir had started off his IPL career with the Daredevils.
Gambhir and Yuvraj, good friends, have been discarded from the Indian team and stay in Gurgaon. The tweet was of course a friendly banter but the episode could set the tone for the rest of the tournament.
Yuvraj is known for his wry humour while Gambhir has been in trouble for his ill-tempered flare-ups in the past. Two years back, he was involved in a fracas with Royal Challengers Bangalore skipper and fellow Delhi player Virat Kohli.
However, on Wednesday, Gambhir had the last laugh, smashing a 43-ball 57 to script a seven-wicket win for the Knight Riders.
Gambhir has led the Knight Riders to lift the IPL trophy twice; in 2012 and 2014.
