heading: Facebook to remove misinformation
content:
Facebook says it will begin removing false information from its site that could lead to violence.
 
“There are certain forms of misinformation that have contributed to physical harm” in certain countries, the U.S. social media giant said in a statement announcing the policy.
 
The company says it will work with local organizations to identify such information, including written posts and doctored photos.
 
Facebook has been accused of allowing users to spread hate speech and false information that has led to recent violence in Sri Lanka, Myanmar, and India.
 
The California-based company was thrust into Russia’s meddling in the 2016 presidential campaign through the spread of misinformation among voters.
 
It was revealed last September that Russians, using fake names, used social media to try to influence voters ahead of the election.
 
Facebook founder and chief operating officer Mark Zuckerberg sparked criticism yesterday when he tried to explain the difference between misinformation and offensive speech.
 
In an interview published by the technology news site Recode, Zuckerberg said he would not ban people who deny the Holocaust, the mass genocide of 6 million European Jews carried out by Nazi Germany.

heading: Nation Building Tax (Amendment) bill passed
content:
The Nation Building Tax (Amendment) Bill was passed with amendments in Parliament yesterday (Jul 18).
 
An amendment was put forward to remove several sports equipment and accessories from being taxed with the aim of developing the tourist industry,
 
An amendment was also submitted for removing the tax on imported gems which are to be re-exported, chisel and beautification items.
 
In addition, amendments were also put forward for the removal of tax on high technology agricultural equipment and coconut based products.

heading: Handing over of Mattala to India, only a Joint Venture agreement says Minister Nimal Siripala
content:
Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva says the discussions with India, is to create a Joint Venture to run the Mattala International Airport.
 
The Minister said this in Parliament today (Jul 19) in response to a question posed by the leader of the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, Anura Kumara Dissanayake.
 
He assured that the agreement on the Mattala JV would be submitted to the cabinet, Attorney General, and the Parliament before the deal is finalized.
 
Meanwhile, the adjournment debate on the revelation made by the New York Times on former President Mahinda Rajapaksa is now underway.

heading: SLFP organizer in Kelaniya accuses Minister Fonseka
content:
The Sri Lanka Freedom Party organizer for Kelaniya, Thilak Waragoda says that Peliyagoda Police has not taken any action against two complaints lodged against Minister Field Marshal Sarath Fonseka.
He revealed this while responding to a statement made by Minister Fonseka on Waragoda.

heading: Minister Mano Ganesan says implementation of death penalty not finalized
content:
Minister Mano Ganesan says that a final decision has yet to be taken regarding the implementation of the death penalty for repeat offenders of drug trafficking.
 
He said this speaking to the media in Colombo yesterday (Jul 18).
 
Meanwhile, five youths from Mahawilachchiya in Anuradhapura have agreed to be volunteers to carry out the role of the executioner.
 
However, a senior Prison Department official said that the post is not Gazetted as yet.
 
He said there are two vacancies for the job.

heading: Joint Opposition prepares to surround Prime Minister’s office
content:
The Joint Opposition is planning to surround the Prime Minister’s Office to stage a protest against the leasing of Mattala International Airport to an Indian company.
 
A Joint Opposition representative told our news team that the protest will be held next month.
 
Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva told a group of Joint Opposition MPs yesterday (Jul 18) that the decision to lease the airport to an Indian company was taken by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.
 
In addition, the Joint Opposition decided during a meeting yesterday, to stage a protest against the delay of elections for the North Central, Sabaragamuwa and Eastern provincial councils.
 
The terms of each provincial council have already lapsed.
 
Several members of the SLFP of Group of 16 including MPs, S.B. Dissanayake, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa and W. D. J. Senevirathna were present at the meeting.
 
However, it is reported that MP, Dayasiri Jayasekera did not participate.

heading: MP Seenithambi offered Rs. 50mn bribe
content: MP Seenithambi Yogeshwaran revealed in Parliament today that he received a telephone call offering Rs. 50 million if he remains silent on the liquor factory which is being built and belonged to Arjun Aloysius in Batticaloa area.Speaking further, the MP said that liquor shopowners have attempted to offer him similar bribes in the past as well. He said that he objected to 67 liquor shops in Batticaloa.

heading: Indian national arrested with Rs. 9.6mn worth drugs
content: An Indian national has been arrested at the Bandaranaike International Airport by Police Narcotics Bureau for possessing 806g of Methamphetamine or 'Ice' worth Rs.9.6 million.

heading: Vijayakala writes to UNP investigation committee
content:
Former State Minister of Child Affairs, Vijayakala Maheswaran has written to the UNP investigation committee regarding the controversial statement she made on the revival of the LTTE.
 
In her letter, she had noted that such a statement was made as she was disappointed with the recent developments in the North.
 
The letter was written in response to a request made by the UNP investigation committee on presenting facts regarding her statement.
 
A 4-member committee comprising of UNP ministers was appointed to carry out an investigation to look in to as to why such a statement was made by MP Vijeyakala Maheswaran.
 
The UNP General Secretary, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, Chairman of the party Kabir Hashim, Ranjith Maddumabandara and Thalatha Atukorala are part of this committee.
 
Meanwhile, the Police Organized Crimes Prevention Division said yesterday that the statements recorded on her controversial remarks will be sent to the Attorney General.
 
Around 25 statements have been recorded including those from Minister Vajira Abeywardena, Northern Province Chief Minister C.V Vigneswaran, district secretaries of Mulativu and Vavuniya districts, as well as Samurdhi officers and Grama Niladari officers who were present at the event when the MP made that statement.

heading: Delay in upcountry trains
content:
The Railway Main Control Room says due to a derailment of a train nearby the Peradeniya Station, that the trains on the upcountry line could be delayed.
A train plying from Polgahawela to Kandy had derailed last night.
The Railway Main Control Room said steps are being taken to renovate the damaged rail track.

heading: Close associate of Makandure Madush arrested
content:
A close associate of underworld kingpin Makandure Madush, Joseph Kumara alias ‘Josa’ and three of his accomplices were arrested in Welipenna.
 
Police said that they found firearms and drugs in the possession of the suspects.

heading: Minister Wijeyadasa clarifies controversy of Galle Stadium
content:
The Higher Education and Cultural Affairs Minister, Wijeyadasa Rajapakse told Parliament today (Jul 20) that UNESCO has not informed to not play matches in the Galle International Cricket Stadium.
 
He said this while answering a question posed by MP Chandima Weerakkody who drew the attention of the House to the reports with regard to relocating the Galle Stadium.
 
Speaking further, Minister Rajapakshe said that a group of officials has already assigned to look into the matter and submit a report within two weeks.
 
He said that the government has not taken any decision to relocate the stadium but steps would be taken only to demolish the controversial buildings from the stadium premises.
 
Rumors were circulated that measures would be taken to shift the Galle International Cricket Stadium.
 
The authorities are planning to demolish the unauthorized buildings within the premises.
 
Several factions opined with regard to this action and, a former cricket captain Mahela Jayawardene also requested the government to reconsider the relocation of the stadium.
 
In a Twitter message, Jayawardene stated several remarkable Test matches were played in Galle and a decision to relocate it is regrettable.
 
He further said that the national team displayed their highest performances and won several outstanding matches in Galle.
 
At the same time, posters are pasted around the stadium today against the alleged relocation of the stadium.
 
Meanwhile, Galle Municipal Council protests against the decision to remove the Mahinda Rajapaksa sports complex.
 
Galle Mayor Priyantha Sahabandu told our news team that such a decision would cause inconveniences to the council.

heading: Export-Import controller arrested for soliciting a bribe
content: The Bribery Commission officials have arrested the Export-Import controller while accepting a bribe of Rs. 200,000 from a businessman.

heading: New hope for President
content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says that during his term he aims to make Sri Lanka achieving the number one rank amongst the anti-graft countries.
President Sirisena said this while speaking at the Special UN group for Jakarta Fundamentals held in Colombo this morning (Jul 25).

heading: HIRU TV's 20th anniversary : Lucky winner of seventh car from Divulapitiya
content:
The loyal viewers of HIRU TV's Tele Perahara now has a chance to win a Rs. 2.5 million worth Mahindra REVSe2o car on five days of the week.
 
The seventh winner of this competition was found today and he is K. A. K. Indika from Divulapitiya.
 
HIRU TV's Tele Perahara runs from 7.30 pm to 9.55 pm on weekdays.
 
The respective winner will be chosen through a SMS competition.
 
A question will be posed during a tele drama, and the viewers can send the answer via SMS to HTP (space) (number sequence of the answers) (space) name, NIC number, area and send the SMS to 7766.
 
The winner of that respective day will be appeared on the screen during the "Thaamath Adare Nathnam" tele drama.

heading: Artillery bombs found in Mullaitivu
content:
Two artillery bombs and several small bombs have detected in an abandoned well in Suhanthipuram in Mullaitivu.
 
Those were found yesterday (Jul 18) following information received by Sri Lanka Navy unit, operating there.
 
After police were notified, Sri Lanka Navy personnel with the assistance of bomb disposal squad retrieved the explosives from the well.
 
Police said that the bombs will be defused after obtaining a court order.

heading: Former OIC of Welikada Police to be jailed
content: Supreme Court orders to implement the 1-year prison sentence imposed on former OIC of Welikada Police Kamal Amarasinghe for assaulting a lawyer.

heading: Gold smuggling attempt by Indians foiled
content:
Four Indian passengers aged 24, 25, 26 and 32 years respectively were arrested by Sri Lanka Customs at around 2.30 am today (Jul 18) while they were trying to smuggle out 12 pieces of gold biscuits.
 
The Customs were alerted by the Airport Security Staff.
 
The find was weighing 235.91g and the estimated value was Rs. 1.53 million.

heading: Cardiac surgeries at Karapitiya resumed
content:
The cardiac surgeon at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, Dr. Namal Gamage said that the cardiac surgeries at the hospital have resumed.
 
He said that the surgeries are now performed with the work to renovate the central AC system of the Intensive Care Unit being started.
 
The surgeon decided to stop cardiac surgeries at the KTH on 14th of this month as authorities were not taking steps to renovate the malfunctioning central AC system of the ICU.
 
After surgeries are performed patients are kept at this ICU and several patients had died as a result of the defective AC system.
 
Meanwhile, sources at the National Hospital, Colombo said renovation activities are taking place at its cardiac unit too very often.

heading: Heavy Traffic in Town Hall
content:
Heavy traffic in the Town Hall area due to a protest march by South-Eastern university students.
 
Our correspondent said that Ward Place has been temporarily closed.The protest is held against a move by the university administration to suspend classes of 17 students and eviction of four students from the university.

heading: UNP Central Working Committee convenes to discuss Vijayakalaa issue
content:
The Central Working Committee of the United National Party will meet to discuss the issue of MP Vijayakala at Sirikotha today (Jul 25).
The committee which had looked into the alleged pro-LTTE statement made by the MP will be presented at the meeting today.
Party General Secretary, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, chairman, Kabir Hashim and Ministers, Ranjith Madduma Bandara and Thalatha Athukorala were part of this committee.
The Central Working Committee meeting will be chaired by Prime Minister, Ranil Wickremesinghe.
In addition, the UNP Working Committee will discuss the forthcoming provincial council election and the proposed 20th constitutional amendment.

heading: Bharatha's bodyguard started firing first and Duminda got hit first - State Counsel tells in court
content:
The Deputy Solicitor General, Thusith Mudalige told before the Supreme Court today (Jul 18) that shots were first fired on the head of former MP, Duminda Silva and, the shooting was first started by a bodyguard of Bharatha Lakshman, Gamini.
 
The appeal by former MP Duminda Silva requesting the court to acquit him was taken again for consideration before a bench of 5 Supreme Court Judges chaired by Chief Justice Priyasath Depp today.
 
Making the submission on behalf of the Attorney General’s Department, the Deputy Solicitor General said that Bharatha Lakshaman’s bodyguard, Gamini fired the shots first and former MP Duminda Silva fell on the ground after he received Gamini’s gunshots in his head.
 
During previous hearings, the president counsels stated that it was proved by some evidence during the High Court trial that former MP Duminda Silva was shot at first and the medical reports have also proved that Duminda Silva received gunshots in his forehead.
 
The president counsels further said that the verdict against former MP Duminda Silva has been given neither on the evidence nor on the facts but based on his personality as a popular political icon.
 
The said that although the verdict is read one hundred thousand times, it is not possible to understand why former MP Duminda Silva has been convicted.
 
Thus, they pointed out that the verdict which convicted former MP Duminda Silva is neither actual nor authentic.
 
They said that the High Court judge has given the verdict based on the opinions submitted by the state counsels but without examining whether the evidence is proven beyond reasonable doubt.
 
The president counsels further pointed out before the Supreme Court that the High Court has ignored the submissions made by the defendant and has conducted the trial merely based on the fictitious incidents and evidence.
 
They said that this case was filed to tarnish the image of former MP Duminda Silva, therefore, he has been denied a justifiable trial similar to that of any other citizen is entitled to in this case.
 
In addition, the president counsels further pointed out before the Supreme Court that the evidence in every incident that was given to make former MP Duminda Silva guilty was contradictory.
 
They said that the verdict has itself stated that such evidence given by the witnesses could not be accepted as 100% correct.
 
They said former MP Duminda Silva has been made guilty of charges which are not included in the indictment and, that is not legal at all.
 
They said despite the omissions and contradictions were pointed out in the High court they were not taken for proper consideration in giving the judgment. They stated that the CID has made false charges against former MP Duminda Silva by fabricating such incidents.
 
The president counsels pointed out before the Supreme Court that charges were made against former MP Duminda Silva on using firearms but they did not produce any evidence to prove them during the trial.
 
In addition, charges were made that former MP Duminda Silva intimidated voters but the Court was of the opinion that such charges have no any truth.
 
Therefore former MP Duminda Silva should be acquitted of the charge that he acted under a common agenda, they noted.
 
The president counsels said that the security guards of former MP Duminda Silva have returned fire under the vested power in them to perform their duty after Bharatha Lakshman’s faction started firing first.
 
They said the investigators have created false incidents to make former MP Duminda Silva somehow a culprit of this incident.
 
They said that such facts including the report of the Government Analyst and other evidence were produced during the High Court trial, former MP Duminda Silva was convicted without taking such concrete evidence into consideration.
 
The further hearing will be held on Friday.

heading: Bail decision on Aloysius & Palisena to be taken on October 11
content:
The Court of Appeal ruled today (Jul 18) that the decision on the bail application filed by the owner of Perpetual Treasuries Limited's owner Arjun Aloysius and its CEO Kasun Palisena will be announced on 11th of October.
 
The relevant bail application was taken up before the Court of Appeal President Preethi Padman Surasena and Shiran Gooneratne.

heading: President Sirisena details Sri Lanka’s fight against corruption (Photos)
content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says that unlimited power creates corruption and during the last three years, Sri Lanka took several important steps to break the link between power and corruption in the country.
 
He made this statement at the Open Government Partnership Global Summit in Tbilisi in Georgia today (Jul 18), while intervening at the Summit Session at the Tbilisi Conference and Concert Hall.
 
The Global Session, chaired by Georgian Prime Minister Mamuka Bakhtadze with the participation of Presidents, Prime Ministers, Speakers, Ministers and other representatives from 75 member countries.
 
The Open Government Partnership is a mechanism formed to enhance transparency and accountability to the public and peoples participation in governance.
 
President Sirisena spoke at the session under the theme, “How the decisions taken at the OGP could be used for the welfare and benefit of the people of the member countries?”

heading: Microfinance loans of women in 12 districts written off
content:
Cabinet approves to write-off microfinance loans less than Rs.100,000 issued to women in 12 districts affected by drought.
Further, the government has also decided to introduce an interest rate cap of 30% per annum on all future loans given by Microfinance Companies.
This scheme of relief initially will be limited to women who have obtained microfinance loans for non-consumption purposes in the drought-affected districts.
The twelve districts that were affected by the recent drought are Trincomalee, Ampara, Batticaloa, Jaffna, Mullaitivu, Kilinochchi, Vavuniya, Mannar, Kurunegala, Puttalam, Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa where cultivations were affected consecutively for five seasons.

heading: Statements recorded on Vijayakala's remarks to be sent to AG
content:
The Police Organized Crimes Prevention Division says that the recorded statements in connection with the pro-LTTE remarks made by former State Minister, Vijayakala Maheswaran will be sent to the Attorney General.
 
It added that they have recorded statements from 25 persons.
 
Statements have been recorded from Minister Tilak Marapana, Vajira Abeywardena, Northern Chief Minister, C. V. Wigneshwaran, Districts Secretaries of Mullaitivu and Vavuniya and several Samurdhi officers and Grama Seva Officers in the area.
 
In addition, it is scheduled to record a statement from MP, Vijayakala Maheswaran today or tomorrow.
 
MP Maheswaran stated that the LTTE should be revived during a ceremony held in Jaffna on 2nd of July.

heading: Accident on A-9, 18 injured (Photos)
content:
18 persons were injured in an accident occurred in Poonewa on the A-9 road early this morning.
 
A Colombo bound CTB bus from Puthukudiiruppu had veered off the road and hit a roadside tree.
 
Police said 18 injured passengers had been admitted to Vavuniya Hospital.
 
The driver had fallen asleep on the wheel, causing the mishap.

heading: Two teachers sexually abuse schoolgirl, upload footage in Facebook
content:
Two teachers arrested"Two teachers have been arrested for the alleged abuse of a female Advanced Level student from a school in Monaragala.
 
Police said one of them was attached to a school in the same area, while the other was a private tuition teacher.
 
According to police, the first teacher had lured the victim to his private residence, promising to teach her history.
 
He had then proceeded to sexually assault her.
 
Later, the second teacher, a friend of the first, had abused the girl at the same premises.
 
It has also been revealed that the incident was filmed and has been uploaded to Facebook by the two accused teachers.
 
Police stated that similar complaints have been received against the two suspects in the past.
 
They were produced before Monaragala Magistrate today (Jul 25).

heading: Infant's father and three others remanded
content:
Four persons including the father of a toddler who had fed his 13-month old infant with an alcoholic beverage have been remanded until 1st of August.
 
They were produced before Galgamuwa Magistrate today (Jul 18).
 
The relevant video was telecasted via HIRU TV news and based on that police arrested four persons including the infant's father yesterday.
 
The suspects are residents of Meegalewa in Anuradhapura.Police produced the smartphone that used to record the incident and the liquor bottle to the courts.

heading: British MP Ian Paisley suspended over Sri Lankan government-funded holidays
content:
The Democratic Unionist Party MP Ian Paisley Junior has been suspended from London’s House of Commons for 30 sitting days and had his salary withdrawn for a month.
It comes at the end of an investigation into two holidays taken by the Northern Ireland politician and his family, funded by the Sri Lankan government back in 2013.
His absence is likely to last until October, as the UK parliament goes into recess this week and does not sit again until September 4th.
Speaker of the House John Bercow called it "a regrettable state of affairs".
Bercow will now formally inform the chief electoral officer of the decision and she has ten working days to set up a petition which, if signed by 10% of North Antrim constituents will lead to a by-election and Paisley having to stand down.
Sir Kevin Barron, chair of the Standards Committee, said they had concluded Paisley was guilty of "serious misconduct".
Paisley has apologized for not declaring two family holidays paid for by the Sri Lankan government.
It will also be a blow to British Prime Minister Theresa May, who is relying on the DUP’s 10 MPs to keep her government in power through a confidence and supply agreement.

heading: $ 100mn World Bank aid to modernize Sri Lanka education system
content:
Sri Lanka today signed a $100 million credit agreement with the World Bank to support Sri Lanka’s efforts to strengthen and modernize the general education system in the country.
 
The General Education Modernization Project (GEM) will modernize and diversify the curriculum of general education in keeping with the transformation taking place in the Sri Lankan society and economy.
 
The project will help broaden choices at the GCE A-level grades so that students have the flexibility in selecting subjects from among the arts,
management, science, technology, and vocational streams.
 
Learning material for English language and Mathematics will be developed digitally and the focus will be on children from schools located in more disadvantaged regions.
 
The project will benefit school students both at the primary (grades 1-5) and at the secondary (grades 6-13) levels.
 
Technical education and vocational training institutes, the academic and managerial staff of the schools will also benefit from this project.

heading: Seven Indian fishermen arrested off Kankesanthurai
content:
Sri Lanka Navy has apprehended seven Indian fishermen along with two vessels in the seas off Kankesanthurai for breaching Sri Lanka's territorial waters.
 
The arrest was made early this morning (Jul 24).
 
The Indian fishermen were to be handed over to Jaffna Fisheries Inspector's Office and thereafter to be produced before Mallakam Magistrate.

heading: Update : Police use tear gas to disperse HND students’ protest
content:
Police used tear gas to disperse a protest march by the students of the Higher National Diploma.
 
The protest march is held urging the authorities to increase the Mahapola scholarship payment to Rs. 5,000.
 
They began the protest march from Punchi Borella this afternoon.

heading: Second accused in Kotakethana double murder acquitted
content:
The second accused in the murder of a 52-year-old mother and her 17-year-old daughter of Kotakethana in Kahawatta has been acquitted after 6 years in remand prison.
 
The Colombo High court acquitted the accused, Ashoka Chandani Kumari alias Batti after determining that there was insufficient evidence against her.
 
The High Court Judge, Vikum Kaluarachchi ordered to hear the case against the first accused, Lokugamhewage Darshana alias Raju on 1st of November.
 
Nayana Nilmini and Kavindya Chaturangi were murdered at Kotakethana in Kahawatta on 31st of January, 2012.
 
Later, a married couple, Lokugamhewage Darshana and Ashoka Chandani Kumari were arrested in connection with the crime.

heading: Two arrested in Kalpitiya sea with gold
content: Sri Lanka Navy has arrested two persons in the seas off Kalpitiya with 5.7kg of gold.The estimated value of the detection was Rs. 40 million.

heading: Body of Indika Ginige taken to home (Photos)
content:
The body of late popular singer and actor Indika Ginige is now kept at his home in Kandy.
 
The final rites will be held at the Mahaiyawa cemetery at 4 pm tomorrow (Jul 26).Earlier, it was planned to hold the funeral this evening.
 
He died after being admitted to the Kandy General Hospital following a sudden illness on Monday.
 
He was 37-years-old, at the time of his demise.
 
Indika Ginige was married and he had a 7-year-old daughter and she is living abroad with her mother.
 
It was reported that Ginige was having health issues since of late.
 
His father had told police that the door of his son's room remained locked on Monday and then they opened the door forcibly and found the son in a state of unconscious.
 
Later, he was rushed to the hospital where he was pronounced dead.

heading: HIRU TV's 20th anniversary : Lucky winner of 11th car from Ratmalana
content:
The loyal viewers of HIRU TV's Tele Perahara now have a chance to win an Rs. 2.5 million worth Mahindra e20 car on five days of the week.
 
The 11th winner of this competition has been found and she is W. K. Imali Indika from Ratmalana.
 
HIRU TV's Tele Perahara runs from 7.30 pm to 9.55 pm on weekdays.
 
The respective winner will be chosen through an SMS competition.
 
Several questions will be posted during teledramas, and the viewers can send the answer via SMS to HTP (space) (number sequence of the answers) (space) name, NIC number, area and send the SMS to 7766.
 
The winner of that respective day will appear on the screen during the "Thaamath Adare Nathnam" teledrama.

heading: GMOA to strike on August 3
content:
The Government Medical Officers' Association emphasized that they will launch a one-day token strike on 3rd of August.
 
The GMOA is planning to stage this strike against the Sri Lanka - Singapore Free Trade Agreement.

heading: Police record statement from MP Maheshwaran
content:
Former State Minister Vijayakala Maheshwaran gave a statement to the Police Organized Crimes Prevention Division regarding the statement she made that the LTTE should be revived.
 
A senior police officer told us that the statement, which was recorded at her home in Jaffna for almost three and a half hours.
 
The MP had told the Police Organised Crimes Prevention Division officials that she had made the statement concerned due to emotional feelings triggered by the increase of incidents of woman and child abuse cases taking place in the Northern Province.
 
Meanwhile, an officer said that ITAK leader, MP Mavai Senathirajah also gave a statement with regard to her statement and it took approximately 2 hours.
 
An official confirmed that statements are scheduled to be recorded from two others.

heading: Gotabaya Rajapaksa rejects social media reports
content:
Former Defence Secretary Gotabaya Rajapaksa rejected a media release being circulated in the social media claiming that he has been appointed as the Presidential Candidate for 2020.
 
The former Defence Secretary made this announcement in a Facebook message.

heading: Verdict on Ven. Gnanasara's defamation case on August 8
content:
The Court of Appeal today (Jul 18) announced that the verdict on the case filed by the Attorney General against Ven. Galagodaaththe Gnanasara Thera for defaming the court will be announced on 8th of August.
 
This was ruled when the case was taken up before the President of the Court of Appeal, Justice Preethi Pathman Surasena and Justice Arjuna Obeysekere.
 
Our correspondent said that Ven. Galagodaaththe Gnanasara Thera was present in the court when this order was given.Ven. Gnanasara Thera has been accused of contempt of court following his unruly behaviour on the day when journalist Prageeth Eknaligoda’s disappearance case was taken for hearing in Homagama Magistrate Court.Later, the Attorney General pressed charges Gnanasara Thera under four counts of charges including challenging the honour of the judiciary.

heading: JVP questions legality of SL – Singapore FTA
content:
A special debate on the much-discussed Sri Lanka – Singapore Free Trade Agreement was held in Parliament yesterday (Jul 18).
 
Joining the debate, the parliamentarian of the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna Sunil Handunnetti questioned as to how the Attorney General had given permission for the Sri Lanka – Singapore Free Trade Agreement.
 
He pointed out the FTA was not passed in Parliament.
 
MP Wimal Weerawansa, State Minister Niroshan Perera, Deputy Minister Nalin Bandara and MPs  Sunil Handunnetti and Ramesh Pathirana expressed their views on this occasion.

heading: Ampara government servants oppose political interference (Photos)
content:
Many public servants in the Ampara district have worn black armbands today (Jul 18) to oppose a plan to transfer the District Secretary due to political pressure.
 
Our correspondent said the front entrance of the District Secretariat has been decorated with black.
 
The protesting employees charge that plans are drawn to transfer the District Secretary and few other top public officials in the district as they had implemented a request by a politician.

heading: Are footballers behind Galle cricket ground fiasco? UNESCO also in doubt
content:
The General Secretary of the Sri Lanka UNESCO Commission, Premalal Rathnaweera says that those who are in favour of removing the Galle International Cricket Stadium are those who were engaging in playing football during the period when the stadium was a public ground.
However, he added that in the communique issued by UNESCO with regard to the Galle Stadium, there has been no recommendation on abolishing the stadium.
Meanwhile, participating in the Hiru TV Salakuna political programme yesterday, Sports Minister Faizser Mustapha noted that he possesses all documentation which could prove that the construction of the Galle international cricket stadium is legal.
If the UNESCO, the National UNESCO commission and certain government Ministers are not in favour of abolishing the stadium as they state, isn’t it a question as to who has the dire need of abolishing the Galle International Cricket Stadium?

heading: Joint Opposition members visit Transport Ministry
content:
A group of Joint Opposition parliamentarians visited the Transport Ministry this morning (Jul 18).
 
They had discussed with Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva on the government's plan to set up a Joint Venture to run the affairs of the Mattala International Airport.
 
An Indian firm has been approached to set up the proposed JV.

heading: Tuition activities banned from July 31 for A/L
content:
All tuition classes, revision classes and other activities related to A/L examination will be prohibited from 31st of July 31 to 1st of September.
 
The Department of Examinations said that for Grade 5 scholarship examination tuition related activities are banned from 1st of August.
 
The Grade 5 scholarship examination will be held on 5th of August while the 2018 GCE A/L will start from the next day.

heading: ETI depositors complain to Central Bank
content:
The ETI depositors today handed over letters to the Central Bank, Finance Ministry and Presidential Secretariat informing those institutions of the injustice caused to them by the ETI management.
Police, however, blocked the depositors' protest march towards the Central Bank.
It created a tense situation.Our correspondents said knowing in advance of the protest march, the police roadblocks were ready well before the protestors start their march towards the CBSL.
They marched towards the CBSL in a disciplined manner and a high ranked police officer took steps to remove the protestors from there.
Later, four representatives from the protestors were allowed to enter the CBSL premises to hand over the letter.
They also handed over letters to Finance Ministry and the Presidential Secretariat.
However, after noticing that an individual was following them, the depositors confronted him.
Thereafter, the ETI depositors had a discussion with President's Coordinating Secretary Sunanda Kariyapperuma.

heading: Draft of new constitution ready
content:
A preliminary draft relevant to the new constitution is scheduled to be presented to the constitutional steering committee today.
 
A member of the committee said that the preliminary draft had been prepared based on the interim report the constitutional council’s steering committee has currently released and the reports of the six sub-committees.
 
The constitutional steering committee is scheduled to meet at parliament complex at 2.30 pm today (Jul 18).
 
The committee member said further that the final draft would be presented in Parliament after views of political parties are obtained.

heading: Public assistance sought to locate missing George Keyt paintings
content:
The Criminal Investigation Department has requested the support of the public in order to identify two suspects who have stolen two paintings of the famous artist George Keyt.
The two paintings are reportedly worth over Rs. 12 million.
The two paintings named 'Mother and Children' and 'Vasanthi' were reportedly stolen on 12th of July 2013, from an office in Colombo 02.
According to the complaint received, it was stated that the paintings were placed at 130, Glennie Street, Colombo 02 and that prior to the building being demolished, paintings had been stolen.
The CID requests the public if any information is found to contact the Financial Crimes Investigation Division on 011 239 52 48.

heading: Heroin trafficking school security guard arrested
content: A security guard of a leading school in Kuliyapitiya has been arrested in front of the school for possessing six packets of heroin.

heading: Services on up-country line restored
content:
The train services on the up-country line which was interrupted due to a derailment between Hatton and Rozelle stations have been restored.
 
The Railway Main Control Room said that the railway workers were able to repair the damaged track last night.

heading: HIRU 20th anniversary : Sixth car winner from Panadura
content: The sixth car was offered to a lucky viewer of the HIRU Tele Perahara today (Jul 17).After the SMSs with correct answered were drawn, the lucky winner was found from Panadura.She was Anuradha Perera.14 more luxury Mahinda Revae20 cars on offer for those who watch HIRU Tele Perahara from 7.30 pm to 9.55 pm on weekdays.

heading: Police record statement from NPC Chief Minister over Vijayakala's remarks
content:
The Police Organized Crime Prevention Division has recorded a statement from the Northern Provincial Chief Minister, C.V. Vigneshwaran in connection with the Pro-LTTE speech made by former State Minister, Vijayakala Maheswaran.
The investigators visited the Chief Minister at his residence in Jaffna at 10.30 am today to record the statement.
The Police Organized Crime Prevention Division had already recorded statements from Foreign Affairs Minister Thilak Marapana and Home Affairs Minister, Vajira Abeywardena.
Both of the Ministers, along with the Chief Minister were present on the stage when MP Vijayakala Maheswaran made the controversial speech.
However, Northern Chief Minister Vigneshwaran released a communiqué later today and said that the police investigators had a cordial discussion with him.
The Chief Minister further said in his statement that MP Vijayakala Maheswaran had explained the insecurity situation in the North.
He stated that if any action is taken against her statement, it would be an obstruction to the rights of the freedom of expression.Meanwhile, a protest was staged in Embilipitiya against the former State Minister's statement today.

heading: One missing after raft capsized in Valachchenai
content:
A raft carrying three fishermen had capsized in Miyanmadu Tank in Valachchenai.
 
One person is still missing after the mishap which occurred yesterday (Jul 17).
 
An operation is underway to locate him, and the victim was aged 56 years, resident of Miyanmadu.

heading: Former JHU MP monk remanded
content:
The Chief Incumbent of Gampaha, Naagasella Sri Vivekaaraama Temple, Venerable Aparaekkkey  Pagngnaananda Thera has been arrested for allegedly abusing an under-aged boy.
 
Later the monk was remanded till 26th this month.
 
Police arrested the 63-year-old monk and was produced before the Attanagalla Magistrate court.
 
The monk was arrested last forenoon (Jul 18) after a complaint was lodged with police that the suspected monk had allegedly abused a 9-year-old under-aged boy.
 
Aparaekkkey  Pagngnaananda Thera was elected as an MP at the 2004 general election from the Jaathika Hela Urumaya.
 
Police said that the child is now receiving treatment at the Gampaha Hospital.

heading: Seven fishermen found stranded in deep seas return
content:
The seven fishermen who were stranded in deep seas off the Maldives, located through an international search operation, have returned to the island.
 
They left the shores from the Galle Fisheries Harbour and their relatives even staged a protest blocking the Galle road, urging the authorities to find the missing men.

heading: Minister Sagala says crimes should be prevented even by giving harsh punishments
content:
Minister Sagala Ratnayake says that organized crimes including drug trafficking should be curbed by implementing harsh punishments.
 
Addressing an event in Weligama, the Minister said the government is paying special attention to crimes such as drug trafficking.

heading: Oluvil campus suspends 17 students & sacks 4
content:
17 students attached to the Faculty of Technology of the South Eastern University have been suspended for ragging a group of newcomers.
In addition, the enrolment of four others who involved in the ragging has been cancelled.
At the same time, the disciplined students were asked to vacate their hostels by noon yesterday but the university administration complained to the police as they had not left the hostels.
The video footage on which university security staff armed with clubs and sharp objects had searched the hostels for the suspended students, is shared on social media.

heading: Oversees visits banned indefinitely for ETI board of directors
content:
The ban of overseas visits for the board of directors of the ETI Finance Limited of Edirisinghe Group has been extended indefinitely by Colombo Fort Magistrate, Lanka Jayarathna today (Jul 18).
Accordingly, Jeevaka Edirisinghe, Nalaka Edirisinghe, Deepa Edirisinghe and Asanka Edirisinghe have been banned from travelling overseas indefinitely. The court issued the travel ban after considering the submissions made by the Attorney General's Department.
The company is accused of not paying the billions of deposits made by the general public including pensioners in the ETI.The ETI directors convened the depositors a number of times promising to repay the money, but they are yet to fulfill their commitments.The depositors handed over letters to the Central Bank, Finance Ministry and Presidential Secretariat highlighting their plight.

heading: Basil Rajapaksa permitted to go abroad
content:
The Matara Magistrate today (Jul 24) gave permission to former Minister Basil Rajapaksa to go abroad.
 
He had sought permission from the court through a motion that he wanted to go abroad to get medical treatment for a period of three months.
 
Accordingly, Matara Additional Magistrate Nilmini Kusum Vitharana gave the permission to the former Minister to go abroad.
 
His passport was impounded earlier in a case filed by the Financial Crimes Investigation Division under the Money Laundering Act over acquiring of a 1 1/2 acre land in Browns Hill Matara.

heading: Cause for Indika Ginige's death revealed !
content:
Sources say that popular singer and actor Indika Ginige had died after consuming a high dosage of a non-prescribed medicine.
 
The 37-year-old actor fell sick suddenly and was taken to Kandy General Hospital where he was pronounced dead.
 
The married actor was living alone in Kandy and his wife and daughter are living abroad.
 
The funeral will be held tomorrow at the Mahaiyawa cemetery in Kandy at 4 pm tomorrow (Jul 25).

heading: Gusty winds predicted to hit three provinces
content: Strong gusty winds up to 50-60 kmph can be expected over the Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central provinces and in Kalutara district.

heading: No delay in Special High Court, first one to be set up next week
content:
All steps have been taken to establish the first court of the Special High Court set up to try cases of bribery, criminal breach of trust, misappropriation, money laundering, terrorist financing, organized crime and offenses against public property.
 
A member of the Parliamentary Oversight Committee on Legal Affairs and Anti-Corruption, Ajith P. Perera said that its activities can be commenced next week as its construction has been completed and judges have been appointed.
 
Media reports were published that it may take up to about a month to commence the activities of the Special High Court.
 
Failure to appoint a registrar and having only one out of the three courts gazetted as yet were provided as reasons behind the said delay.
 
However, State Minister Ajith P. Perera stated that all steps have been taken to establish the first court of the Special High Courts.

heading: 10-year-old boy missing in Balangoda forest
content:
The search operations to find the 10-year-old boy who has gone missing since last Friday, in Samanalawatta, Balangoda is continued for a fourth day.
 
 A military squad joined the search operation yesterday.
 
The missing child is a grade-five student of the Samanalawatta Vidyalaya.
 
On Friday, the child had left the home saying that he was going to the forest to meet his father, who was collecting firewood inside the forest.However, area residents fear that a leopard that was roaming in the area might have harmed the child.

heading: Moragahakanda - Kalu Ganga reservoir to be filled
content:
President Maithripala Sirisena will commence the water filling of Kalu Ganga reservoir today.
 
The reservoir was constructed under the Moragahakanda- Kalu Ganga project.
 
The inauguration ceremony is to be held today in the Laggala- Kalu Ganga bund.
 
The project which is the final phase of the Mahaweli project expands over 666,000 acre-feet at a cost of 2300 million rupees.
 
The capacity of Kalu Ganga reservoir is 265 million cubic meters and will divert 100 million cubic meters of water a year to the Moragahakanda Reservoir.

heading: Principals & teachers warn of political appointments
content:
The Education Administrative Services Union and Teacher and Principal Unions say that unless the 1018 appointments scheduled to be made based on political favouritism are nullified, they will refrain from scholarship and A/Level examination duties.
 
The unions say that these appointments are being given for political supporters in the guise of those who had been politically victimized.
 
Similarly the Trade Union Collective for Safeguarding Education announced that it requests Provincial Directors and the Education Ministry to postpone the term test scheduled for 26th of this month as a one-day strike is to be launched.

heading: Changing Executive Presidency not timely; a statement from Asgiri Anu Nayake Thera
content:
The Anu Nayake Thera of the Asgiri Chapter, Most Venerable Anamaduwe Dhammadhassi Thera says that changing the Executive Presidency or constitutional amendments are not timely at the moment. 
The Anu Nayake Thera made this statement when the Chairman of Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna, Professor G. L. Peiris paid a courtesy call on the Thera.

heading: Man who steals money from friend's ATM card arrested (Photos)
content:
Vavuniya police arrested a person who had stolen money from the ATM card of his friend.
 
The suspect was a resident of Embilipitiya.
 
His friend had given him the ATM card with the secret number to get him some money.
 
However, that the suspect in the guise of a blind man had asked a woman nearby an ATM of a state bank in Vavuniya, to withdraw Rs. 100,000 on behalf of him from the ATM.
 
However, the woman after realizing that the man was not actually blind, had informed about it to a few youths.
 
Then the youths had given chase to the suspect and had caught him and had handed over him to the police.
 
It was found that the suspect had withdrawn Rs. 100,000 more than what was asked by his friend.

heading: PM assures in Vijayakala's presence 'LTTE will not revive again'
content:
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe says that he can guarantee that the LTTE will not be able to revive once again in Jaffna.
 
Speaking at an event held in Jaffna today, which was also attended by former State Minister Vijayakala Maheshwaran, the Prime Minister Wickremesinghe made this statement.
 
Earlier, MP Maheshwaran said that she would like to see the revival of the LTTE in Jaffna.
 
Following this statement, she was asked to resign from her State Ministerial post.

heading: Wife axed to death by husband
content:
Police have launched an investigation to arrest the husband of a woman who had been murdered using an axe.
 
The incident had occurred in Nakulugamuwa in Galagama, Beliatte.
 
The victim was 59-year-old and police said that she had been killed following a family dispute.
 
The suspect had fled the area following the killing.

heading: Body of undergrad fallen from Asupini Ella found
content:
The body of the undergraduate whose body could not be located after falling into Asupini Ella on Saturday has found this afternoon (Jul 17).
 
The body was found at a location from where water is channeled to generate hydropower.
 
He had fallen into the water as he had attempted to take a photograph from nearby the waterfall.
 
The villagers said that so far 14 persons who had visited the area on sight-seeing fell into the waterfall.
 
They said most of the visitors ignore the warning not to get closer to the waterfall.

heading: Sri Lankans to witness longest lunar eclipse
content:
Sri Lanka stargazers will be able to witness another celestial phenomenon at the end of this month.
 
They will be able to witness the longest total lunar eclipse of the century on 27th of July, the Esala Full Moon Poya Day.
 
The lunar eclipse will begin at 10.45 pm and then will end at 4.58 am, the next day.
 
The world witnessed another super lunar eclipse in January this year.

heading: Six heroin traffickers arrested from Matale remanded
content:
The six heroin traffickers who were arrested with 332 heroin packets from Viharagala in Haputale have been remanded until 26th of this months.
 
The suspects who were arrested yesterday were produced before Bandarawela Magistrate.
 
Police found 8.379g of heroin, 401mg of cannabis and babul in the possession of the suspects when the lorry by which they were travelling was checked.

heading: Large cache of bombs and ammunition found in Mullaitivu (Photos)
content:
A large number of bombs and explosives were detected after excavating a land in Sudanpuram in Mullaitivu, where an LTTE training camp believed to have existed.
 
Our correspondent said the land was excavated for three days under tight security after obtaining a court order.
 
The excavation work began following a tip-off received by the Navy Camp in the area.

heading: Global fuel prices increase, what will happen in Sri Lanka ?
content:
Global fuel prices have risen again after falling or staying stable for a month as international rates have jumped and the dollar becoming strong against most of the currencies.
 
Since June, crude oil has gained more than $ 6 to reach $79.5 a barrel as the United States is seeking stronger compliance of its sanctions against Iran that traders fear could substantially reduce oil supply from the market.
 
The decision of a cartel of key oil-producing countries to raise output by a million barrels per day is seen as insufficient to meet the rising demand and has aided the recent surge in prices.
 
Sri Lankan oil prices also could impact as the rupee continues to dip against the US dollar.
 
In line with the fuel pricing formula introduced by the Finance Ministry, the next price revision is scheduled to take place on 10th of August.

heading: Two girls drown in Kalutara
content: Two girls aged 11, from Modera drowned in the seas off Calido beach,  Kalutara, last evening and died at Nagoda hospital early this morning.

heading: Over two kilos of narcotics found in East
content:
Special Task Force has arrested two persons in Ichchlampattu in Serunuwara with 2.069kg of narcotics believed to be heroin.
 
They were arrested last evening.
 
The suspects aged 42 and 46, are residents of Karamalai and Ichchalampattu.
 
The suspects have been handed over to Serunuwara Police.

heading: Galle Intl. Cricket Stadium to be shifted
content:
It has been decided to declare the Galle International Cricket stadium a public sports ground.
 
This will support the preservation of the Galle Fort as a world heritage site.
 
The decision was taken during a meeting held among the secretaries of the Ministries of culture, sports, southern development, internal affairs and officials of the Galle Heritage Foundation and the Galle Cricket Stadium.
 
A few days ago, the UNESCO informed that all buildings in the Galle Cricket Stadium are unauthorized structures. 
 
Therefore, UNESCO informed that it has to delist the Galle Fort from the World Heritage sites list.
 
It further informed that such construction should be removed before December in 2019.
 
Meanwhile, officials in charge of the Galle International Cricket Stadium stated that a location in Pinnaduwa has been earmarked to build a new cricket stadium.
 
However, a senior official said since it will cost around Rs. 700mn to construct a new stadium, the proposal will be reviewed before a decision is made.

heading: Villager attacked by a bear
content: A villager from Sampathnuwara, Mullaithivu was admitted to Vavuniya General Hospital after he was attacked by a bear.He came under attack inside a forest in Mullaithivu yesterday (Jul 16).Hospital sources said that the condition of the villager is not critical.

heading: Strike by education sector called off
content: Teacher trade unions say that the strike action by education sector employees planned for tomorrow was temporarily called off following a discussion with the President.

heading: 16-hour water cut in some parts of Gampaha district
content: National Water Supply and Drainage Board says a 16-hour water cut will be enforced from 8 am tomorrow (Jul 15) in Kelaniya, Peliyagoda, Wattala, Biyagama, Mahara, Dompe, Ja -Ela, Katunayaka, Seeduwa, and parts of Gampaha.

heading: Few members of Group of 16 to return to SLFP
content:
Minister Dr. Sarath Amunugama says that few members of the Group of 16 who left the government will return to the Sri Lanka Freedom Party very soon.
Joining a media conference in Kandy, he said few of them have conveyed their decision.
Meanwhile, the General Secretary of the United People's Freedom Alliance, Minister Mahinda Amaraweera says that MP Dayasiri Jayasekera has not requested the post of General Secretary of the SLFP.
Minister Amaraweera said this responding to journalists following an event in Kurunegala yesterday (Jul 13).

heading: Person who allegedly fed infant with liquor traced
content:
The man who had allegedly fed a little boy with a drink which seemingly looked like liquor has been identified by police.
The video of the incident is currently going viral on social media.
Addressing a media conference in Colombo, Police Media Spokesperson, SP Ruwan Gunesekera said that the man is identified as a resident of Ganangamuwa, Meegalawa in Anuradhapura.
He said a statement was recorded from the man today.

heading: Transport associations go to Human Rights Commission against increase of spot fines
content:
Several transport associations will seek the intervention of the Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission against the increase of spot fines against traffic violations.
 
They will file a complaint with the SLHRC today (Jul 16).
 
Private Bus Associations and All-island Motor bicycle Association are among those who had joined the effort.
 
The new spot fines against traffic violations came into effect from yesterday.

heading: Fifth winner of HIRU car competition announced
content: K. M. Nilanthi Pushpakumari of Wennappuwa has won the fifth luxury Mahindra Reva e20 car which is given to the lucky winners of HIRU Tele Perahara.The competition is held to mark the 20th anniversary of Sri Lanka's most popular TV channel HIRU TV.Under this programme, 20 cars will be offered to the lucky winners of an SMS competition.

heading: Tamil National Alliance seeks police powers to North
content:
The Tamil National Alliance says that the Northern Province should be given police powers in order to reduce the crimes in the province.   
 
The TNA parliamentarian, M. A. Sumanthiran made this statement speaking to media following a ceremony in Jaffna today (Jul 21).
 
The MP stated that the provincial council should receive powers pertaining to law and order to control the prevalence of crimes in the North.
 
The MP further stressed that individuals who speak the language of the North should be recruited to the police.
 
Parliamentarian Sumanthiran also stated that they will do the maximum to force the government and that they also wish to discuss this matter with the Prime Minister during his visit to the North.

heading: GPS a must for tippers
content:
The Geological Survey and Mines Bureau says that the tippers transporting gravel and sand should possess the GPS technology.
The Bureau's Chairman Asela Iddawela says they will not issue permits to tippers that do not have the GPS technology.

heading: SB, WDJ and Susil to attend Joint Opposition party leaders' meetings
content:
Three parliamentarians from the 'SLFP group of 16' are prepared to attend the Joint Opposition party leaders' meetings in the future.
According to a request made by MP S. B. Dissanayaka from the Joint Opposition, MP Susil Premajayantha and W. D. J. Senevirathna will also participate in the meetings.

heading: No quorum in Parliament again
content:
The Chair of the Parliament had to ring the bell again today (Jul 20) as there was no quorum in the House.
 
JVP MP Bimal Rathnayake was at the chair then and MP Sisira Jayakody highlighted the lack of quorum.
 
The bribery amendment bill is being debated now.

heading: Litro Gas seeks price increase
content:
State-owned domestic gas retailer Litro Gas Company has made a request to increase the price of a domestic gas cylinder again.
The Managing Director of the company Muditha Peris said that the request was made during the Cost of Living Committee meeting held on 11th of this month.
When we contacted the Chairman of the Consumer Affairs Authority, Anura Maddegoda regarding the matter, he stated that although it was discussed during the committee meeting, gas companies have not given any written submissions.

heading: "Lokka" arrested over Maradana shooting
content:
The underworld figure, Ravindra Sanjeewa alias "Lokka" who was accused of causing injuries to three youths during a shooting in Maradana last year, has been arrested by the Colombo Crimes Division.
 
The 29-year-old suspect is a resident of Colombo 12 and he was arrested yesterday in Dematagoda.
 
The shooting incident took place on 29th of August in 2017.
 
Police found a revolver, five 9mm pistol bullets and 20g of Kerala cannabis in his possession.

heading: First shot fired by Bharatha Lakshman’s bodyguard Gamini critically injuring Duminda Silva precipitated all other events thereafter - Presidents Counsel tells Supreme Court
content:
Presidents Counsel Anil Silva impressed upon the court that if Bharatha Lakshman’s bodyguard had not fired the first shot at Duminda Silva’s head causing grievous hurt, all other resultant and subsequent events would not have happened.
 
The appeal by former MP Duminda Silva seeking the Supreme Court to acquit him was again taken up by the five bench Supreme Court judges chaired by Chief Justice Priyasath Dep.
 
Presidents Counsel  Anil Silva responding in reply to Attorney General Department’s verbal submission earlier summarized several facts and placed before the court, points on which all parties including the attorney general’s department agreed upon, which includes;
 
 
 * No firearm handled by Duminda Silva at any time during the day under review
 * Former MP Duminda Silva did NOT fire a single shot at any given time
 * The meeting of the two parties was accidental
 * The First shot was fired at Duminda Silva causing grievous hurt to his head, who fell unconscious to the ground instantly
 * Duminda Silva was immediately evacuated from the scene of the incident and rushed to the Hospital
 
 
In addition, the President’s Counsel reiterated that Bharatha Premachandra’s bodyguard “Gamini” fired the first shot injuring Duminda Silva, as emphasized by the attorney generals Department, which in fact precipitated and ignited all subsequent events.
 
He also said that Duminda Silva who received grievous penetrating gunshot injuries to his head, fell unconscious and was immediately removed to the hospital, and as such cannot be held responsible for any events that took place thereafter.
 
He posed the question, how under these circumstances Duminda Silva, who was unconscious and evacuated immediately from the scene, could be made guilty of a Murder Charge.
 
He emphasized that the evidence given by a single witness “interested” due to his close association with Bharatha Lakshman whose statements to the CID was belated, could be considered while disregarding all other versions of all other prosecution witnesses especially those made by trained government security officers.
 
Further, the President’s Counsel stated that the narration of this single interested witness cannot be reconciled, when considering forensic evidence of experts and judicial medical officers.
 
He echoed that irrespective of all these important facts which were analytically placed before the Trial at Bar, none of these had been considered at the time of delivering the majority trial at bar verdict, probably as they were clouded by the desire to convict the 11th accused.
 
The Counsel pointed out that Duminda Silva was deprived of a fair trial even though the judgement itself says that none of the witnesses can be relied upon 100%.
 
 
Extracting points from the High Court Judgement itself, Anil Silva placed before the Supreme Court instances where the investigators have threatened and intimidated witnesses to fall in line with the false evidences fabricated by them and making those who did not compromise listed as accused.
 
Here again, all instances of falsification had been placed before the Trial at Bar judges, but completely ignored in arriving at the majority judgement.
 
 
Presidents Counsel   Anil Silva pointed out that the Attorney Generals department had admitted in their written submissions to the trial at bar “If only the Himbutana shooting incident occurred the accused could not have been charged in the manner they have now being charged”.
 
Presidents Counsel concluded saying under these circumstances the investigators worked backwards and fabricated events to implicate and charge Former MP Duminda Silva.
 
Further, Presidents Counsel  Anil Silva pointed out that the verdict delivered finding Duminda Silva guilty was presented by one learned judge and since the other supporting learned Judge had not given his reasoning, the judgement by its self does not stand acceptable in its true sense.
 
The 3rd Learned Judge who had delivered the dissenting judgement at the trial at bar had acquitted all accused including Duminda Silva from all charges.

heading: Three given death sentence over murder
content:
Colombo High Court judge Vikum Kaluarachchi sentenced three persons to death over a murder of an individual in November 1996.
 
The convicts had hacked the victim to death in Pannipitiya on 2nd of November, 1996 and caused critical injuries to the victim’s wife.
 
One of the convicts who was accused of causing critical injuries to the woman was given 7 1/2 years of rigorous imprisonment.
 
The convicts were residents of Pannipitiya.

heading: Gunman attempts to kill a businessman
content:
A gunman on a motorcycle had attempted to open fire at a businessman in Kamburupitiya, Matara last night.
However, the gunman's firearm had malfunctioned.
Thereafter, the gunman had sped away with his accomplice.

heading: Two schoolboys drown in Veyangoda
content: Two 16 and 17-year-old school boys have drowned while bathing in the "Dee Ella Oya" in Veyangoda.The incident had occurred at around 1.30 pm. They had died after admitted to Wathupitiwala Hospital.

heading: Railway technical staff launches a work-to-rule agitation
content:
The railway technical staff and technical assistants say they will resort to a work-to-rule campaign from midnight today (Jul 22).
 
They have cited several job-related issues as the reason for the trade union action.
 
Issues relating to a 40-hour duty week and over-time disparities are among them.
 
The General Secretary of Railway Technical Management Assistants' Union W. B. S. Kamal Peiris said although they have highlighted their issues a number of times, the authorities have failed to address them.
 
The Union said because of this trade union action, there will be delays in trains from Monday.

heading: Police say ‘Gunathilaka’ faces no charges over rape case
content:
Sri Lanka Cricket on Sunday night announced that it had decided to suspend Danushka Gunathilaka from all forms of International cricket for breaching "player code of conduct".
 
The SLC statement did not specifically mention the reason for the pending suspension.
 
It said, "The decision to suspend the player was taken following an initial inquiry conducted by Sri Lanka Cricket after the team management reported that the player has violated the Code of Conduct".
 
However, the story began to unfold yesterday.
 
The suspension comes after a Norwegian woman had accused Gunathilaka's friend of allegedly raping her in a hotel room where Gunathilaka was also present.
 
It was reported that Gunathilaka and his friend took two Norwegian women to the hotel where the player was staying in Colombo in the early hours of Sunday (Jul 22).
 
One of the women later accused the second man, a British passport-holder of Sri Lankan origin, of raping her.
 
Later police arrested the 26-year-old suspect.
 
The Norwegian woman had made the complaint of rape to the police unit at the Bandaranaike International Airport.
 
The woman had undergone a medical test and the case had been transferred to Colpetty Police.
 
Meanwhile, the police said that it will not press charges against the Sri Lankan opening batsman relating to the allege rape case.

heading: Two persons missing as raft topples
content: Two persons are missing and three others were rescued after a raft toppled in Malagane Tank in Wariyapola.Police said that the group had gone to pluck lotus leaves.It was reported that five persons have ventured into the water on the raft and three of them were able to swim ashore after the mishap.The missing persons are residents of Gampaha.

heading: Three persons including a policeman arrested over Maha Oya policeman's death
content:
Three suspects including a police constable and a civil defence force personnel were arrested over the death of a police constable attached to the Maha Oya police.
  
On the 18th of this month, the body of the police constable J. P. Samanthilaka Jayasingha was recovered.
 
The relatives of the deceased policeman accused that the killing was an inside job.
 
Following the post-mortem, it was revealed that the deceased policeman was severely beaten to death.
 
Thereafter, the three men were arrested on suspicion of the murder.

heading: World Bank extends $ 200mn to control non-communicable diseases
content:
The Minister of Health says that the World Bank has extended $ 200mn to control non-communicable diseases.
 
Under this project, a concept named 'family doctor' will be strengthened.
 
The Ministry said this strategy will be launched in August this year.

heading: Matara shops closed as a mark of respect
content:
Our correspondent says that the funeral of the police officer who was killed during a gunfire with a group of robbers in the Matara town will be held this evening (Jun 24). 
He said that the shops in Matara are closed for 2 hours this afternoon as a mark of respect for the slain policeman.

heading: Two arrested over Kilinochchi leopard killing
content:
Police have arrested two persons over the recent killing of a leopard in Ambalkulam in Kilinochchi.
 
A 42-year-old resident of Ambalkulam was arrested first and thereafter another suspect surrendered to police.
 
He was a resident of Udayanagar and was aged 39.
 
The suspects will be produced before Kilinochchi court today (Jun 24).

heading: “Publication of some annexes of bond report may be prejudicial” – AG informs
content:
The Attorney General has informed that the publication of some annexes of the bond report may be prejudicial to several ongoing cases.
 
The AG has conveyed this in response to a clarification sought by the Presidential Secretary.

heading: Two remanded over killing a leopard in Kilinochchi
content:
Two suspects who were arrested over the killing of a leopard in Ambalkulam, Kilinochchi have been remanded until 29th of June.
 
The Kilinochchi Magistrate also ordered to arrest other suspects.

heading: President leaves for Italy
content:
President Maithripala Sirisena left the island this morning (Jul 14) for Italy on a three-day state visit.
Our airport correspondent said that a delegation of 20 was with President.

heading: Traffic congestion in Nawala
content: Heavy traffic congestion in and around Nawala area due to a protest demonstration by Open University students.

heading: SLFP's "Group of 16" meets Wimal
content:
A discussion was held between the SLFP's "Group of 16" and the National Freedom Front at its headquarters in Pitakotte this afternoon (Jun 26).
MPs. W. D. J. Seneviratne, Susil Premajayantha, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa and several other group members participated.
Following the discussion, the NFF leader, Wimal Weerawansa said that several matters including a move to demand the Opposition Leader's position for former president Mahinda Rajapaksa were discussed.

heading: Wendaruwe Upali Thera clarifies his statement
content:
Asgiri Anunayaka Venerable Wendaruwe Upali Thera says he didn't mean a  malicious rule like Hitler in his statement at the event to mark former Defence Secretary Gotabhaya Rajapaksa's birthday.
 
He said he highlighted the need for straight policies.

heading: Investigations underway to arrest Kilinochchi leopard killers
content:
Police say that they have already identified some of the suspects who were involved in killing a leopard in Ambalkulam in Kilinochchi.
 
The suspects have been identified by examining video footage.
 
A senior officer at the Kilinochchi Police stated that investigations are underway to apprehend four such identified suspects.
 
Kilinochchi Magistrate Court yesterday ordered police to examine video footage and arrest the suspects who were involved in clubbing the leopard to death.

heading: UPFA MP Tharanath Basnayake to join Joint Opposition
content:
United People’s Freedom Alliance’s Parliamentarian Tharanath Basnayaka who recently resigned from his Deputy Ministerial post has said that he is prepared to leave the Sri Lanka Freedom Party and continue his political journey with Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.
 
The MP said that he with work with the Joint Opposition in Parliament from next week onwards.
 
However, MP Prasanna Ranathunga addressing media in Minuwangoda yesterday said that if the Group of 16 SLFPers want to join the Joint Opposition, they should leave the SLFP.

heading: Kosgoda Tharaka's mother remanded
content:
The mother of Kosgoda Tharaka has been remanded until 4th of July.
She was arrested after it was revealed that one of the motorcycles used by the Matara robbery suspects is registered under her name.
The main suspect in robbery "Kosgoda Tharaka" is in the ICU of Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, along with two other suspects.
Police investigations are underway to arrest two more suspects.

heading: Matara robbery suspects remanded
content:
Court has ordered the three suspects including Kosgoda Tharaka arrested in connection with the robbery of a jewellery store in Matara to be remanded till 2nd of next month.
 
Meanwhile, Police have commenced a special operation to arrest two suspects who had fled following the robbery.
 
Police Media Spokesperson SP Ruwan Gunasekara said that one of the suspects has been identified.
 
A suspect in the robbery, Chamara Indrajith who attempted to hurl a grenade at the Police was killed by Police fire last night.
 
He had previously been wanted over several crimes including murders as well.
 
Police Media Spokesperson SP Ruwan Gunasekara said that the suspect had attempted to hurl a grenade while being escorted to locate a bag belonging to him in the Kiralakele area in Matara.
 
The mastermind of the robbery Tharaka Perera Wijesekera alias Kosgoda Tharaka is still receiving treatment at the Karapitiya hospital ICU.
 
Kosgoda Tharaka and his brother Mahesh exchanged fire with police and, the two suspects who received injuries during the shooting were left over nearby the Karapitiya Hospital.
 
Then the people in the area had hospitalized them.
 
Later it was found they were among the group who had committed the Chicago-type robbery in Matara.
 
A police officer was killed, and four others including 2 policemen were injured in the shootout when thieves broke into a jewellery shop in Matara last morning (Jun 22).

heading: Hidden LTTE explosives and arms cache found in Tamil Nadu
content:
The Tamil Nadu Police have recovered a large quantity of ammunition and explosives on a coastal hamlet in Rameswaram following a tip-off.
 
A resident of Anthoniyarpuram spotted a box of bullets while constructing a septic tank in the backyard of his house.
It is believed that the explosives unearthed are from the 1980s and of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam.
Trinitrotoluene detonators, detonator launchers and more than 50 boxes of ammunition were found.

heading: Expressway buses to join Southern bus strike !
content:
National Transport Commission says that the services of the drivers and conductors of the Southern long-distance buses will be cancelled from the day after tomorrow (Jun 28), if they do not report to work today.
 
The Chairman of the NTC, M. A. P. Hemachandra requested the bus operators to stop the strike.
 
Meanwhile, five Sri Lanka Transport Board buses were pelted between Galle and Ambalangoda last night.
 
Police have arrested a suspect for allegedly throwing a stone at a bus nearby the Ambalangoda, Urawatte Bridge.
 
Aruna Halpe, the Chairman of the Matara Passenger Transport Company, said if their issues are not addressed they would launch a continuous strike with the support of the bus operators of the Southern Expressway.
 
The office workers were greatly inconvenienced as a result of the strike during this morning as well.
 
The Southern Province's long-distance bus operators began their strike after they were not allowed to stop buses at short distance bus halts.

heading: Three students arrested over murder of head prefect ordered to be kept at a Children's Home
content:
The three students are accused of killing the head prefect of Savarana Muslim Vidyalaya were ordered to be kept at a Children's Home.
 
The order was issued by District Judge and Chilaw Magistrate Manjula Ratnayake.
 
The suspects will be kept at the Children’s Home until 3rd of July.
 
The suspects, who were aged 15 and was in Grade 10, had clubbed the victim to death when the victim was returning home after attending a religious event at the mosque.
 
The victim was initially admitted to Chilaw Hospital and thereafter transferred to National Hospital, Colombo as his condition was critical.
 
However, he succumbed to his injuries after 13 days.

heading: Several other unions to support postal strikers
content:
The Joint Postal Trade Unions Front says that it will stage a protest in Colombo on Monday (Jun 25) with the participation of several main trade unions to urge the government to provide solutions to their demands.
 
The union is already engaging in a continuous fast in front of the Colombo Central Mail Exchange.
 
The President of the National Trade Union Centre, Politburo member of the JVP, K. D. Lalkantha visited the premises this morning in order to support the strikers.
 
Meanwhile, the Convener of the Joint Postal Trade Unions Front, Chinthaka Bandara noted that they will continue with the strike action until authorities provide reasonable solutions to their demands.

heading: Southern private bus strike called off
content: Long distance private bus operators in South called off their strike, after National Transport Commission offered them a discussion.

heading: Galle Face entry road closed
content: Galle Face entry road has been closed from Lotus round-about due to a protest march by disabled policemen.

heading: Traffic along Marine Drive from Wellawatte to Colpetty to be restricted
content: Police say that the traffic along Marine Drive from Wellawatte to Colpetty will be restricted from 7 am to 3 pm tomorrow (Jun 24) due to National Cycling Championship.

heading: Postal workers to call on chief prelates
content:
The Joint Postal Trade Union Front says that they would call on the Chief Prelates of the Asgiri and Malwathu chapters to make aware of their ongoing struggle.
 
The Postal employees are continuing their strike for the 14th day over several demands including a service structure which is unique for the Postal Department.

heading: Husband arrested for killing newly-wed wife
content:
Police say a newly married woman succumbed to her injuries while being treated at the Puttalam Hospital yesterday (Jun 23).
 
She had been attacked with a knife by her husband two days ago following a family dispute.
 
The victim was aged 23.
 
Her husband had also cut his abdomen with a knife after stabbing the victim and was admitted to Puttalam Hospital.
 
Later he was arrested and remanded until 4th of next month.

heading: 4 arrested in Oddusudan with a claymore, handed over to TID (Photos)
content:
Four persons who were arrested following the recovery of a 15 kg claymore mine and several other military items have been handed over to the Terrorism Investigation Division.
 
Two persons were initially arrested while transporting the items in a three-wheeler and thereafter two more persons were arrested.
 
Police have widened the probe to apprehend another suspect who had run away from the three-wheeler.
 
The arrest was made at around 5.30 am yesterday (Jun 22).
 
Police found 120 T-56 bullets, 10 electronic detonators, 21 normal detonators, 2 LTTE hand grenades, 6 remote controllers and camouflage kits.

heading: Former LTTE member arrested in Mankulam
content: The main suspect who fled after a haul of arms, explosives, and ammunition seized from a three-wheeler in Oddusudan, has been arrested in Mankulam.A claymore bomb and detonators were among the military items seized.Police arrested two suspects at that moment and then two more suspects were apprehended.All of them were handed over to Terrorism Investigation Division for further investigations.It was found that the latest suspect arrested over the incident was a former LTTE cadre.

heading: I. K. Mahanama & P. Dissanayake further remanded
content:
President's former Chief of Staff I. K. Mahanama and former Chairman of State Timber Corporation P. Dissanayake have been further remanded until 10th of July.
 
They are in remand custody for allegedly soliciting a Rs.20 million bribe from an Indian investor.
The suspects were produced before Colombo Chief Magistrate, Ranga Dissanayake this morning (Jun 26).
 Rejecting bail for the suspects, the Magistrate said that bail cannot be granted considering the amount of the bribe they have accepted.
 He further said that the Court has decided to keep the suspect in remand until the hearing of the case is concluded.

heading: Postal trade unions call off strike
content: The Posts and Telecommunication Officers' Union stated that it decided to call off the strike.Union's General Secretary H.K. Kariyawasam told our news team that the decision was taken this afternoon.
